training-reference/Advisor_Express/00_Ov.title: 00 Overview
training-reference/Advisor_Express/00_Ov.content:
ADVISOR EXPRESS - OVERVIEW

Overview
Advisor Express is an enhanced front-end product for First Rate Advisor that provides users with quick, easy access to portfolio research and performance reports. Upon logging into Advisor Express, authorized users may click a portfolio ID or filter the displayed portfolios to view associated reporting information.

RIGHT PANE FEATURES:
The right pane of Advisor Express provides the following tabbed data:

Point-to-Point Tab
- Provides monthly and partial-month daily returns for two user-supplied dates
- Click the links to generate the Holdings (Values) Listing or Transaction Listing reports for the selected date range

Returns Tab
- Provides value and return data for the default sector group for month-to-date, 3 month, year-to-date, or inception-to-date time periods
- Click the links to generate the Sector Detail (Master Listing) or Returns (Portfolio Listing) reports

Allocation Tab
- Displays a value allocation pie graph for the selected portfolio
- Click any pie piece to view a sector and value listing, or drill down to the sector, asset, and ticker levels if desired

LEFT PANE FEATURES:
The left pane of Advisor Express provides links to the following reports:

Portfolio Statement
- Generates a portfolio statement for the selected As of Date
- Runs any Advisor report group for the selected As of Date and benchmark group

Selected Group Reporting
- Generates a Master Performance Listing for a group of portfolios based on selected filter values

SOURCE: First Rate Performance Measurement Training Manual, Page 83/86

training-reference/Advisor_Express/01_Us.title: 01 User Prerequisites
training-reference/Advisor_Express/01_Us.content:
ADVISOR EXPRESS - USER PREREQUISITES

User Pre-Requisites
To set up Advisor Express for your organization, you must:

1. Implement portfolio security
2. Set up Advisor Express global variables

PORTFOLIO SECURITY
First Rate Administration's Security -> Users page allows you to enable or disable Advisor Express for each individual user by providing the applicable permissions.

GLOBAL VARIABLES
Although Advisor Express is part of the base First Rate Advisor product, its features must be enabled by setting certain global variables. These global variable settings are available in First Rate Administration's Features -> Global Settings menu.

GLOBAL VARIABLE CONFIGURATION TABLE:

GLVAR ID: 191
GLVAR Description: Log into Advisor Express
Default: N
Function: Determines whether First Rate Advisor user first log into First Rate Advisor or First Rate Advisor Express.

GLVAR ID: 192
GLVAR Description: Show link to Advisor Express in Advisor
Default: N
Function: Determines whether First Rate Advisor includes a link to First Rate Advisor Express. For environments that do not use First Rate Advisor Express, GLVARs 191 and 192 will be set to No.

GLVAR ID: 193
GLVAR Description: Default benchmark group for Advisor Express
Default: 500
Function: ID of the default benchmark group for First Rate Advisor Express portfolio statements.

GLVAR ID: 194
GLVAR Description: Default sector group for Advisor Express
Default: 501
Function: ID of the default sector group for First Rate Advisor Express portfolio statements.

GLVAR ID: 195
GLVAR Description: Default report group for Advisor Express
Default: 524
Function: ID of the default report group for First Rate Advisor Express portfolio statements.

SOURCE: First Rate Performance Measurement Training Manual, Page 84/87

training-reference/Advisor_Express/02_Po.title: 02 Portfolio Security
training-reference/Advisor_Express/02_Po.content:
ADVISOR EXPRESS - PORTFOLIO SECURITY

Portfolio Security
First Rate Administration's Security -> Users page allows you to enable or disable Advisor Express for each individual user by providing the applicable permissions.

SECURITY CONFIGURATION:
- Access is controlled on a per-user basis
- Permissions are managed through First Rate Administration
- Navigate to Security -> Users page to configure individual user access
- Each user can be enabled or disabled for Advisor Express functionality
- Proper permissions must be assigned for users to access Advisor Express features

ADMINISTRATION PATH:
First Rate Administration -> Security -> Users

FUNCTION:
Individual user permission control for Advisor Express access and functionality.

SOURCE: First Rate Performance Measurement Training Manual, Page 84/87

training-reference/Advisor_Express/03_Gl.title: 03 Global Variables
training-reference/Advisor_Express/03_Gl.content:
ADVISOR EXPRESS - GLOBAL VARIABLES

Global Variables Configuration
Although Advisor Express is part of the base First Rate Advisor product, its features must be enabled by setting certain global variables. These global variable settings are available in First Rate Administration's Features -> Global Settings menu.

ADMINISTRATION PATH:
First Rate Administration -> Features -> Global Settings

CONFIGURATION TABLE:

GLVAR 191: Log into Advisor Express
- Default Value: N
- Purpose: Determines whether First Rate Advisor user first log into First Rate Advisor or First Rate Advisor Express
- Impact: Controls the default login destination for users

GLVAR 192: Show link to Advisor Express in Advisor
- Default Value: N
- Purpose: Determines whether First Rate Advisor includes a link to First Rate Advisor Express
- Impact: For environments that do not use First Rate Advisor Express, GLVARs 191 and 192 will be set to No

GLVAR 193: Default benchmark group for Advisor Express
- Default Value: 500
- Purpose: ID of the default benchmark group for First Rate Advisor Express portfolio statements
- Impact: Sets the default benchmark group used in portfolio statements

GLVAR 194: Default sector group for Advisor Express
- Default Value: 501
- Purpose: ID of the default sector group for First Rate Advisor Express portfolio statements
- Impact: Sets the default sector group used in portfolio statements

GLVAR 195: Default report group for Advisor Express
- Default Value: 524
- Purpose: ID of the default report group for First Rate Advisor Express portfolio statements
- Impact: Sets the default report group used in portfolio statements

IMPORTANT NOTES:
- These variables must be properly configured for Advisor Express to function correctly
- Default values may need to be adjusted based on your organization's setup
- GLVARs 191 and 192 should be set to "No" if not using Advisor Express

SOURCE: First Rate Performance Measurement Training Manual, Page 84/87

training-reference/Advisor_Express/04_In.title: 04 Interface Features
training-reference/Advisor_Express/04_In.content:
ADVISOR EXPRESS - INTERFACE FEATURES

Interface Layout and Features

MAIN INTERFACE:
Advisor Express provides a dual-pane interface with specific functionality in each pane for efficient portfolio analysis and reporting.

RIGHT PANE - TABBED DATA:
The right pane contains three main tabs providing different data views:

Point-to-Point Tab:
- Function: Provides monthly and partial-month daily returns for two user-supplied dates
- Interactive Elements: Click links to generate Holdings (Values) Listing or Transaction Listing reports for the selected date range
- Use Case: Analyzing performance between specific dates

Returns Tab:
- Function: Provides value and return data for the default sector group
- Time Periods: month-to-date, 3 month, year-to-date, or inception-to-date
- Interactive Elements: Click links to generate Sector Detail (Master Listing) or Returns (Portfolio Listing) reports
- Use Case: Standard performance analysis across common time periods

Allocation Tab:
- Function: Displays a value allocation pie graph for the selected portfolio
- Interactive Elements: Click any pie piece to view sector and value listing
- Drill-down Capability: Navigate to sector, asset, and ticker levels if desired
- Use Case: Visual portfolio allocation analysis with detailed breakdown capability

LEFT PANE - REPORT LINKS:
The left pane provides direct access to key reporting functions:

Portfolio Statement:
- Function: Generates a portfolio statement for the selected As of Date
- Alternative Function: Runs any Advisor report group for the selected As of Date and benchmark group
- Use Case: Standard portfolio statement generation

Selected Group Reporting:
- Function: Generates a Master Performance Listing for a group of portfolios
- Filtering: Based on selected filter values
- Use Case: Comparative analysis across multiple portfolios

NAVIGATION FEATURES:
- Portfolio ID clicking for quick access
- Portfolio filtering for focused analysis
- Integrated report generation from multiple access points

SOURCE: First Rate Performance Measurement Training Manual, Page 83/86

training-reference/Benchmarks/Benchmark_.title: Benchmark Reporting
training-reference/Benchmarks/Benchmark_.content:
Benchmark Reporting

Overview:
Depending on the level of control an institution wants to apply, benchmark assignments can be managed in First Rate Advisor using the following methods:

1. Portfolio Default / Benchmark Packaging:
   - Portfolio Default allows an individual benchmark or benchmark package to be assigned at the portfolio level
   - When an end user chooses Portfolio Default in First Rate Advisor, that benchmark or group of benchmarks displays on designated reports
   - This functionality allows clients to ensure that a prescribed benchmark is always reported for that portfolio
   - The Portfolio Default may be combined with other benchmark reporting methods

   Benchmark Package Types:
   A Benchmark Package allows a user to group one or more benchmarks of any type (i.e., market, policy, or blended) into a package and assign that package to a portfolio in First Rate Professional.

   - Single Benchmark Package – Market Index: 
     A managed portfolio may be compared to a single benchmark. If First Rate Advisor must always use a particular benchmark when that portfolio is reported, the package may contain a single benchmark.

   - Single Benchmark Package – Benchmark: 
     At other times for a balanced portfolio there may be a dynamic benchmark, policy benchmark, and component market benchmarks suitable for the package.

   - Multi-Benchmark Package: 
     A client may use a mix of these two types of packages. Particularly with a Separately Managed Account (SMA), the individual component portfolios may have single benchmark packages while the relationship or composite has a multi-benchmark package.

2. Benchmark Groups:
   - Individual users or an administrator can create groups of benchmarks and make them available to First Rate Advisor users for reporting

3. Ad Hoc Benchmarks:
   - This optional feature can be used at run-time to select the set of benchmarks desired for that reporting session
   - The report(s) will ignore the benchmark group or portfolio default group previously selected

4. Portfolio Benchmarks:
   - Any portfolio, composite, or model portfolio tracked on the accounting system can be used as a benchmark for attribution analysis

5. Target Policy Benchmarks:
   - If a portfolio has been assigned a target policy in First Rate Professional, certain reports in First Rate Advisor use the target policy benchmark table to determine which benchmarks to include
   - Benchmarks appear following their associated sector or category

Key Features:
- Multiple benchmark assignment methods
- Portfolio-level benchmark control
- Flexible benchmark grouping and packaging
- Runtime benchmark selection options
- Integration with attribution analysis
- Target policy benchmark integration

training-reference/Benchmarks/Blended_Po.title: Blended Portfolio Specific Benchmarks
training-reference/Benchmarks/Blended_Po.content:
Blended (Portfolio-Specific) Benchmarks

Definition:
First Rate Performance allows you to create a custom or blended benchmark that combines an unlimited number of market benchmarks. Blended benchmarks provide a dynamic, portfolio-specific mix of benchmarks that use one or all of the portfolio's sectors.

Benchmark Association Process:
When defining blended benchmarks, the institution associates the portfolio's performance segments (i.e., asset class, style, or sector) with benchmarks. The benchmark's contribution will be based on the percentage of the performance segment's adjusted beginning balance to the sum of all beginning balances of the segments included in the benchmark definition.

Types of Blended Benchmarks:

1. Asset-Weighted Blended Benchmark:
   - This dynamic blend is specific to the actual allocation of each portfolio
   - The asset-weighted blend can contain an unlimited number of sector-benchmark associations
   - These benchmarks remove the weight variances between the portfolio segments and their benchmarks to provide an overall "stock picking return variance"

2. Policy-Weighted Blended Benchmark:
   - This static blend is based on a stated policy of diversification and is often defined at the institutional level
   - The policy-weighted blend can contain up to 20 benchmarks
   - The total weighting of all constituent benchmarks must be 100
   - Policies are provided to First Rate and the static blend is computed

Historical Assignments:
For both types of blended benchmarks, changes can be made over time, historic assignments will be maintained and will be used in the case of rebuilds.

Key Features:
- Combines unlimited number of market benchmarks
- Dynamic, portfolio-specific benchmark mix
- Uses portfolio's sectors for benchmark association
- Two types: Asset-Weighted and Policy-Weighted
- Maintains historical assignments for rebuilds
- Removes weight variances to show stock picking performance
- Flexible benchmark composition and weighting

training-reference/Benchmarks/Market_Ben.title: Market Benchmarks
training-reference/Benchmarks/Market_Ben.content:
Market Benchmarks

Definition:
You may maintain a variety of benchmarks in your database. A market benchmark can be linked to a specific sector or category so that when you run reports, the associated benchmark is selected.

Examples:
Examples of market benchmarks include:
- S&P 500
- Russell 2000 Growth Index
- 90 Day T-Bill
- And so forth

Benchmark Services:
Additionally, First Rate maintains a subscription with many benchmark services that make benchmarks available through a separate agreement. Please speak with your First Rate representative to obtain additional information on this service.

Fund Returns as Benchmarks:
Fund returns may also be used as a benchmark.

Key Features:
- Can be linked to specific sectors or categories
- Automatically selected when running reports
- Available through First Rate's benchmark service subscriptions
- Can use fund returns as benchmark alternatives
- Provide standard measurement for asset, benchmark, or investor performance comparison

training-reference/Benchmarks/Overview.title: Overview
training-reference/Benchmarks/Overview.content:
Benchmarks Overview

Definition:
In First Rate Performance, you can maintain a variety of different benchmarks for reporting, auditing, and comparison purposes. Benchmarks provide a standard against which you can measure performance for an asset, benchmark, or investor.

Types of Benchmarks:
First Rate Performance uses the following types of benchmarks:

1. Market Benchmarks
   - Variety of benchmarks linked to specific sectors or categories
   - Examples: S&P 500, Russell 2000 Growth Index, 90 Day T-Bill
   - Available through First Rate's benchmark service subscriptions
   - Fund returns can also be used as benchmarks

2. Blended Benchmarks (Portfolio-Specific)
   - Custom benchmarks combining unlimited market benchmarks
   - Asset-Weighted: Dynamic blend specific to actual portfolio allocation
   - Policy-Weighted: Static blend based on stated diversification policy
   - Provides portfolio-specific benchmark mix

3. Target Policy Benchmarks
   - Portfolio-level investment policy definitions
   - Specifies sector allocations, benchmarks, and policy variances
   - Includes zero policy options for custom mappings
   - Integrates with First Rate Advisor reporting

Purpose and Usage:
- Reporting and auditing standards
- Performance comparison and analysis
- Portfolio attribution analysis
- GIPS compliance support
- Custom report generation
- Historical performance tracking

Key Features:
- Multiple benchmark types and configurations
- Flexible reporting and assignment methods
- Historical data maintenance
- Integration with First Rate Advisor
- Custom benchmark creation capabilities
- Partial month benchmark support

training-reference/Benchmarks/Partial_Mo.title: Partial Month Benchmarks
training-reference/Benchmarks/Partial_Mo.content:
Partial Month Benchmarks

Definition:
When your reporting period includes either partial starting months (due to portfolio inception dates) or partial ending months (due to the As of Date), certain First Rate Advisor reports link daily benchmark returns to create partial-month benchmarks.

Requirements:
This occurs only when daily benchmark returns are available for the entire reporting period; daily and monthly data cannot be mixed together.

Data Conversion Process:
If you have daily benchmarks without history but there is monthly history available, you can run a program (FRPINDM2D) to load monthly returns to the daily benchmark returns table for the month-end date.

Key Features:
- Handles partial reporting periods
- Links daily benchmark returns for partial months
- Supports portfolio inception date scenarios
- Accommodates custom As of Date reporting
- Program available for data conversion (FRPINDM2D)
- Requires consistent daily data for entire reporting period
- Cannot mix daily and monthly benchmark data

training-reference/Benchmarks/Policy_Ben.title: Policy Benchmarks
training-reference/Benchmarks/Policy_Ben.content:
Policy Benchmarks (Target Policy Benchmarks)

Definition:
First Rate Performance lets you create a portfolio-level investment policy, or target policy, that determines how portfolio assets should be allocated.

Target Policy Components:
The target policy specifies:
- The sectors in which portfolio funds are invested
- The benchmarks to which sector performance is compared
- The percentage of portfolio funds that are allocated to each sector (from 0 to 100 inclusive)
- The minimum and maximum allowable policy variances

Example Target Policy Structure:
A portfolio's target policy might include sectors like:
- EQUITY (EQ) - Dow Jones Ind Avg (15) - 50.00% Policy, 10.00% Min/Max Variance
- TOTAL FIXED INCOME (FX) - LB Gov/Credit (60) - 30.00% Policy, 10.00% Min/Max Variance  
- TOTAL CASH & CASH EQUIVALENTS (ST) - ML 91 Day Treasury (42) - 20.00% Policy, 5.00% Min/Max Variance
- TOTAL FUND (TF) - Consumer Price Index (99) - 0.00% Policy, 0.00% Min/Max Variance

Total Policy Percentage: 100.00%

Zero Policy Feature:
You can also specify sector-benchmark mappings with zero percent policy weightings, called a zero policy. This data can be loaded into the portfolio benchmark table and updated later with policy values. Some clients use zero policies to create portfolio-level sector/benchmark mappings for custom reports.

Usage in Reporting:
If a portfolio has been assigned a target policy in First Rate Professional, certain reports in First Rate Advisor use the target policy benchmark table to determine which benchmarks to include. Benchmarks appear following their associated sector or category.

Key Features:
- Portfolio-level investment policy definition
- Sector allocation percentages with min/max variances
- Zero policy options for custom report mappings
- Integration with First Rate Advisor reporting
- Flexible sector-benchmark associations

training-reference/Composites/ACE_Compos.title: ACE Composites
training-reference/Composites/ACE_Compos.content:
ACE COMPOSITES (AUTOMATED COMPOSITE ENGINE)

Overview:
First Rate Performance provides an Automated Composite Engine (ACE) that automatically manages the movement of composite constituents based on client-defined sets of business rules. Movement in and out of ACE composites is done through ACE Lights Out batches that build composite performance and update portfolio participation dates.

Technical Configuration:
• Rules are defined and grouped together as a rules package
• The rules package is assigned to a composite account
• The composite must have the aggregate type of "ACE" assigned in order to be included in the nightly batch ACE jobs

Key Benefits:
• Minimizes the chances of human error that can occur with composite management
• Provides security-controlled access by your First Rate administrator
• Manages portfolio participation by defining specific business rules for composite membership
• Integrates performance with a composite management tool

Management and Audit Reports:
ACE provides management and audit reports that are helpful in the GIPS verification process:

1. COMPOSITE CONSTITUENT CHANGES REPORT:
• Provides a list of portfolios that included and excluded during the current period
• If the portfolio was excluded, the reason (or failed rule) is also provided

2. COMPOSITE OVERVIEW:
• Provides portfolio ID, Inception Date and Participation Dates for all portfolios that have been part of the composite for the reporting period

3. PORTFOLIO CONSTITUENT HISTORY:
• Provides a list of all selected portfolios and the composites in which they have participated, including dates

4. ANNUAL DISCLOSURE STATEMENT:
• Provides up to 12 years of information in support of GIPS compliance by composite
• Information includes:
  - Firm market value
  - Composite value
  - Composite % of firm
  - Number of constituents
  - Annual composite gross and net of fee returns
  - Benchmark return
  - Dispersion
  - Standard deviation for the composite and benchmark

Business Rules Management:
• Client-defined sets of business rules control composite membership
• Rules packages can be customized for specific composite needs
• Automated processing reduces manual intervention and errors
• Lights Out processing ensures consistent application of rules

Licensing:
ACE is available as a separately-negotiated license. If your organization requires this functionality, please discuss this with your sales representative.

Operational Workflow:
1. Define business rules for composite membership
2. Group rules into rules packages
3. Assign rules package to composite account
4. Set composite aggregate type to "ACE"
5. ACE Lights Out batches automatically process:
   - Composite constituent movements
   - Performance calculations
   - Portfolio participation date updates
6. Generate management and audit reports for verification

training-reference/Composites/GIPS_Compl.title: GIPS Compliance Composites
training-reference/Composites/GIPS_Compl.content:
GIPS COMPLIANCE FOR COMPOSITES

Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) Overview:
The CFA Institute has developed a set of guidelines for presenting performance calculations to the public. These guidelines are officially known as Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS).

Important Distinction:
• The CFA Institute does not provide guidelines for performance calculation software
• The GIPS guidelines apply only to investment firms
• As a result, a performance measurement application cannot claim to be GIPS compliant
• Only investment management firms can claim GIPS compliance

GIPS Requirements for Investment Firms:
The GIPS guidelines specify several requirements in order for an investment management firm to claim GIPS compliance. All assets under the management of the firm must meet all of the GIPS requirements.

First Rate Performance Calculation Methodology:
First Rate Performance uses calculations that adhere to GIPS guidelines for calculation methodology. The calculation requirements include:

1. TOTAL RETURNS REQUIREMENT:
• Total returns must include income and realized/unrealized gains and losses

2. TIME-WEIGHTED RATE OF RETURN:
• A time-weighted rate of return must be used, or an appropriate approximation
• Including a minimum of monthly valuations and adjusting for cash flows
• Interim returns must be geometrically linked

3. FIXED INCOME SECURITIES:
• Values used to calculate rates of return for fixed income securities must include accrued income

4. COMPOSITE ASSET WEIGHTING:
• Composites must be asset-weighted using beginning-of-period weightings
• Or another method that reflects both beginning value and cash flows

5. CASH AND CASH EQUIVALENTS:
• Returns from cash and cash equivalents held in portfolios must be included in total-return calculations

6. TRADING EXPENSES:
• Performance must be calculated after the deduction of all trading expenses

7. MINIMUM ASSET LEVELS:
• If a firm sets a minimum asset level for portfolios to be included in a composite, no portfolios below that asset level can be included in the composite

GIPS Compliance Disclaimer:
First Rate Performance provides the tools needed to abide by each of these calculation methodology requirements, however, following the requirements does not automatically qualify a firm as GIPS compliant.

Accrual and Cash Accounting:
• GIPS requires accrual accounting for fixed income assets
• GIPS recommends accrual accounting on equity assets with dividends
• First Rate prefers to get accrual information from the accounting system of record
• Custom modules can be provided if necessary
• Option to report values that include or exclude accruals in the total value

Settlement and Trade Date Performance:
Since January 1, 2005, GIPS has recommended that performance be calculated on a trade date basis.

Migration Options:
• If currently calculating on settlement date, can move to trade date as of conversion date
• Can designate a specific date like the beginning of the year or calendar quarter
• Additional crossover issues must be considered when switching from settlement to trade date

Bridge Design Considerations:
• The bridge into First Rate Performance must be designed for trade date performance
• The first month of trade date performance includes what would have been traded in the prior month but not posted in the new month
• First Rate Consulting offers custom programming to backdate trades from current month into prior month
• First Rate does not recommend backdating performance more than one month prior to current month

Trade Date Performance Implementation:
Example: If first month of trade date performance is May:
• The bridge for May would need to pick up all pending trades as of April 30th
• An April 30th trade that settled on May 2nd would appear as a trade on May 1st
• This is as close to April as the performance system can get without backdating trades to a prior month and adjusting holdings

Two Implementation Methods:

1. CREATING TRADE DATE PERFORMANCE BASED ON PENDING TRADES:
• If preliminary performance is required prior to the fourth business day of the month
• Client should send clearly identified pending purchases and sales as of the performance month-end
• Can be in the transaction extract or in a separate feed
• First Rate will adjust the cash and holdings based on those pending trades
• Transaction will be identified as a pending trade for further use

2. SETTLEMENT PROCESSING:
• When the trade settles in the following month, it should be sent in the extract with the original trade date (prior month) and settlement date
• First Rate will reverse the original pending trade or delete it and repost the trade with the settled amount
• If a trade is missed in the original monthly extract and is entered with a trade date in the prior month, it will be processed in the prior month if it is a purchase or a sale

Performance Rebuilding:
• Portfolios with prior month trades will have performance for that prior month rebuilt and restated
• A report is available that lists trades for the prior month and those that are posted further back than the prior month
• Trades posted further back than the prior month trigger performance rebuilding for affected periods

training-reference/Composites/Overview.title: Overview
training-reference/Composites/Overview.content:
COMPOSITES OVERVIEW

Definition:
Composites are created and maintained in First Rate Performance. In most cases, the terms composite and aggregate may be used interchangeably, as composites are generally handled the same as aggregates in First Rate Performance.

Core Function:
The composite function allows you to create a portfolio with rates of return representative of a group of portfolios. You can create composites as Asset Weighted (beginning period asset weighting) or Super Composites.

Portfolio Participation Control:
• You may control a portfolio's participation in a composite by specifying starting and ending dates in the Participation Dates Editor
• Portfolios can move in and out of composites multiple times
• Portfolios can participate in multiple composites, based on changes in Investment objectives or other criteria

Implementation Support:
Your First Rate implementation team will ask questions to clarify your needs for composites.

COMPOSITE TYPES:

1. ASSET WEIGHTED COMPOSITES:
• Most commonly used for strategy composites
• Intent is to measure the average return of a set of accounts with the same strategy or investment objective
• Purpose of aggregating the sub-accounts as an asset weighted composite is to focus on the manager's performance

Asset Weighted Composite Formula:
((UVR*ABMV)+(UVR*ABMV)) / Total ABMV

Where ABMV represents the Adjusted Beginning Market Value computed as:
ABMV = (EMV + EA + I) - ((1 - PF)* + (1 - NF)*) / UVR

Formula Components:
• UVR = Unit Value Return
• ABMV = Adjusted Beginning Market Value
• EMV = Ending Market Value
• EA = External Activities
• I = Income
• PF = Performance Factor
• NF = Net Factor

2. SUPER COMPOSITES:
• Typically used for relationship composites
• Intent is to measure the return for all the family assets
• Focus is on asset growth
• Computed by applying the Modified Dietz to the summed financials of all the underlying sub-accounts

SPECIALIZED COMPOSITE TYPES:

1. Separately Managed Account (SMA) Composites
2. Unified Managed Account (UMA) Composites  
3. ACE (Automated Composite Engine) Composites

GIPS COMPLIANCE:
Composites must adhere to Global Investment Performance Standards (GIPS) guidelines for calculation methodology, including specific requirements for asset weighting, return calculations, and reporting standards.

TECHNICAL IMPLEMENTATION:
• Asset weighted composites use beginning-of-period weightings
• Super composites use Modified Dietz method on summed financials
• Participation dates control when portfolios enter/exit composites
• Multiple composite membership is supported
• Performance calculations must meet GIPS requirements

training-reference/Composites/SMA_Compos.title: SMA Composites
training-reference/Composites/SMA_Compos.content:
SEPARATELY MANAGED ACCOUNT (SMA) COMPOSITES

Definition and Purpose:
First Rate Performance allows you to designate composites as Separately Managed Account (SMA) composite types. A Separately Managed Account composite is an investment vehicle whereby an investment institution outsources portfolio management to an external firm that specializes in a particular style of investing (i.e., Large Cap Growth). These managers have total discretion over a portion of the investor's money and all investment decisions are viewed as being managed in the style.

Key Advantages:
• Provides investors with a multitude of experts instead of being limited to a single institution's expertise
• Provides clients with certain tax advantages, such as avoiding unearned capital gains associated with mutual funds
• Enables ability to direct investment managers to sell certain assets for tax purposes

Benefits for Investment Firms:
• Allows investment firms to market the types of composites they are good at managing
• Enables hiring outside experts to manage other investment styles
• Provides flexibility to shift money to another manager if performance is poor while retaining the relationship with the investor

SMA Composite Structure Example:

Account Type: Household Level

Composite for Person 1 Relationship:
• SMA (Large Cap Growth)
• SMA (Small Cap Core)
• SMA (Fixed Income High Yield)
• Mutual Fund Account
• IRA

Composite for Person 2 Relationship:
• SMA (Large Cap Growth)
• SMA (Large Cap Core)
• SMA (Mid Cap Core)
• SMA (Fixed Income High Yield)
• Mutual Fund Account
• IRA

Composite for Person 3 Relationship:
• SMA (Large Cap Growth)
• Mutual Fund Account
• IRA

Investment Specialization Areas:
The SMA structure allows for specialization in various investment categories:
- Large Cap Growth
- Large Cap Core
- Small Cap Core
- Mid Cap Core
- Fixed Income High Yield
- Plus traditional account types (Mutual Fund Accounts, IRAs)

This structure enables each person's relationship to be managed with a customized mix of specialized managers while maintaining the overall relationship at the household level.

training-reference/Composites/UMA_Compos.title: UMA Composites
training-reference/Composites/UMA_Compos.content:
UNIFIED MANAGED ACCOUNT (UMA) COMPOSITES

Definition and Structure:
UMAs are accounts that have separate managers, but all holdings and models are contained in one account. The challenge in this type of account is that it becomes difficult to track individual manager performance, which is important in the evaluation.

Benefits to Account Holders:
• Lower cost to access outside managers
• Lower operational overhead
• Scalable investment process
• Tax optimization

Technical Implementation:
A UMA vendor separates the accounts into 'sleeves' or sub-accounts which are then loaded into First Rate as accounts. In this manner, each manager can be tracked at multiple levels and manager models can be mimicked more easily. The sleeves (accounts) are then aggregated back together to provide the performance for the UMA.

Two Management Approaches:

1. OPTIMIZATION APPROACH:
• Seeks to report the tax benefit of the UMA in total
• Fewer sleeves (accounts) to reconcile
• Loss of transparency of each manager
• Difficult to decompose the effects of managers on client performance

2. MANAGER REPLICATION APPROACH:
• Provides more transparency by manager
• Requires more accounting overhead
• Better ability to track individual manager performance
• More complex reconciliation process

Strategic Considerations:
The type of reporting approach should align with the value proposition of the investment firm. Firms must balance transparency versus operational efficiency when choosing between optimization and manager replication approaches.

Implementation in First Rate:
• UMA sleeves are loaded as individual accounts
• Each manager can be tracked at multiple levels
• Manager models can be replicated more easily
• Performance aggregation provides total UMA performance
• Multi-level tracking enables both detailed manager analysis and consolidated reporting

training-reference/Data_Management/Accou.title: Accounting Data Review
training-reference/Data_Management/Accou.content:
ACCOUNTING DATA REVIEW

The following accounting data is reviewed:

1. UNITS OUT OF BALANCE (UOOB)
   Definition: Balances for beginning and ending units for all positions reconciled with all transactions that impact units
   
   Indicators: Units Out of Balance can be an indicator of:
   - Missing trade
   - Missing transaction code
   - Improperly classified transaction code
   - Old asset changing its identifier (old asset left with no current units but units in prior time period)
   - New asset identifier will have units at current time frame and no previous units for prior time period
   - In both cases, no transaction will be received from the trust system to account for the asset changes
   
   Special Note: If you wish to exclude cash assets from the UOOB report, you can either flag them individually for exclusion or flag the entire cash sector and set a global variable that allows you to 'Skip UOOB logging for the &CASH sector'

2. CASH OUT OF BALANCE (COOB)
   Definition: Balances for beginning and ending cash positions reconciled with transactions that impact cash
   
   Indicators: Cash out of Balance can be indicator of:
   - Missing transaction
   - Missing transaction codes
   - Improper transaction code
   - Backdated trade that impacted a previous month, along with the cash balance of the portfolio for that previous month
   - In many cases this would also impact UOOB if the backdated trade involves a buy or sale of an asset

3. NO TRANSACTION CODE
   Definition: Client has passed a new transaction code that has no performance effects defined

4. SECTOR CHANGE AUDIT
   Definition: Find holdings moving from one sector to another
   Process: Client confirms that these changes are intended and they are reversed if necessary

5. NO SECTOR AUDIT
   Definition: Finds holdings that have no sectors assigned, and therefore aren't impacting performance as they should

6. ASSET SUMMARY REVIEW
   Definition: Displays detailed asset-level data for selected portfolios and dates, including more than a dozen linked audit reports
   Purpose: Look for asset-level return issues such as:
   - Different asset versus price returns
   - Returns out of tolerance
   - Missing prices
   - And so forth

7. INVALID TRANSACTION PRINCIPAL REPORT
   Definition: Identifies Free Receipt (FR) and Free Delivery (FD) transactions as decided by clients with potential pricing issues

8. PRICE WARNINGS
   Definition: Identifies specific assets that can cause return review exceptions
   Also identifies: Assets that are not priced or have bad prices

KEY REVIEW AREAS:
- Unit balance reconciliation
- Cash balance reconciliation
- Transaction code completeness
- Sector assignment accuracy
- Asset-level performance issues
- Pricing accuracy and completeness

training-reference/Data_Management/Audit.title: Auditing Daily Returns
training-reference/Data_Management/Audit.content:
AUDITING DAILY RETURNS

In the event of a significant cash flow, the performance industry recommends that the portfolio be revalued and a return calculated on the day of the flow. For clients providing daily prices, asset coupon rates, and income payment dates, First Rate will compute daily returns in order to achieve a more accurate one month return for reporting.

DAILY RETURN COMPUTATION REQUIREMENTS:
- Daily prices
- Asset coupon rates
- Income payment dates

REVIEW PROCESS:
- First Rate reviews the resulting monthly return after the end of the month
- If the result of the daily returns is a monthly return that falls outside the tolerances set by the client, then the daily returns will be reviewed for price and accrual issues
- Accounting data is the only data reviewed to determine accuracy of daily returns
- Daily returns themselves are not reviewed for reasonability unless there is a problem with the monthly return

INDUSTRY BEST PRACTICE:
- Portfolio revaluation on significant cash flow days
- Return calculation on the day of the flow
- Enhanced accuracy for monthly reporting

KEY PRINCIPLES:
- Daily returns computed for accuracy when daily data is available
- Monthly return tolerance triggers daily return review
- Focus on accounting data accuracy
- Daily returns reviewed only when monthly returns are problematic

training-reference/Data_Management/Audit.title: Auditing Month to Date Performance
training-reference/Data_Management/Audit.content:
AUDITING MONTH-TO-DATE PERFORMANCE

First Rate conducts a daily review to determine if inbound files were received and loaded into the performance system. If there are issues involving the data, First Rate will notify the client to discuss issues impacting the process.

MONTH-TO-DATE RETURN CHARACTERISTICS:
- Month-to-date returns are considered preliminary and therefore should be used as such
- First Rate will refrain from repairing month-to-date data as transactions are typically being revised, repaired, and corrected for any given month up until three business days after a month-end
- This practice prevents making edits that may be impacted by subsequent data

STANDARD SERVICE LEVEL:
- Daily review of inbound files
- Client notification of data issues
- Preliminary status for month-to-date returns
- Three business day correction window after month-end

CUSTOM REQUIREMENTS:
If your organization requires something other than this standard service level, please discuss those requirements with your sales representative.

KEY CONSIDERATIONS:
- Daily file monitoring and review
- Preliminary nature of month-to-date returns
- Standard correction window to avoid conflicting edits
- Custom service levels available upon request

training-reference/Data_Management/Audit.title: Auditing Returns Overview
training-reference/Data_Management/Audit.content:
AUDITING RETURNS AND COMMON RETURN ISSUES

First Rate relies on quality client accounting data in order to produce accurate returns. If there are consistent issues that prevent the timely computation of reasonable returns, First Rate looks first to the client to correct processes, data, or the accounting system extract. If the client is unable to make the corrections in a timely manner, they will be asked to fund a custom program to repair the accounting issue and increase the release of timely, accurate returns.

RETURN CALCULATION FOUNDATION:
- A return is the result of the Modified Dietz
- The more accurate the data is, the more accurate the return
- We follow a standard process to ensure a return is reasonable based on comparable market benchmarks and client data available

FIRST RATE SERVICE APPROACH:
- We help identify common data and accounting problems that cause questionable returns
- In a First Rate-client relationship, the client assumes ownership for the quality of the accounting data that might impact a return
- An amount provided by the client that is marginally inaccurate may not trigger a return audit, though it could still be considered inaccurate

KEY PRINCIPLES:
- Quality client accounting data is essential for accurate returns
- Client responsibility for data quality
- Standard processes for return reasonableness verification
- Custom solutions available for persistent data issues
- Focus on timely, accurate return delivery

training-reference/Data_Management/Build.title: Build Performance and Flag Portfolios
training-reference/Data_Management/Build.content:
BUILD PERFORMANCE AND FLAG PORTFOLIOS

This represents the core performance calculation process in the First Rate Performance system. After accounting data has been evaluated and any exceptions repaired, the system proceeds to build performance calculations and flag portfolios that require additional review.

PERFORMANCE BUILDING PROCESS:
- Execution of Modified Dietz calculations
- Application of client-specific calculation rules
- Processing of all portfolio data
- Generation of performance results

PORTFOLIO FLAGGING:
- Identification of portfolios with unusual results
- Flagging of returns outside tolerance ranges
- Marking portfolios requiring analyst review
- Prioritization of exception portfolios

QUALITY CONTROL INTEGRATION:
- Automated exception detection
- Performance validation checks
- Benchmark comparison analysis
- Tolerance testing

OUTPUT GENERATION:
- Performance results for qualifying portfolios
- Exception reports for flagged portfolios
- Preliminary performance data
- Status indicators for each portfolio

This process represents the culmination of all prior data management activities, producing the actual performance measurements that will be used for client reporting while ensuring quality through systematic flagging of potential issues.

training-reference/Data_Management/Corpo.title: Corporate Actions
training-reference/Data_Management/Corpo.content:
CORPORATE ACTIONS

Corporate actions can often have an adverse effect on performance unless some additional editing is done. Please notify First Rate or indicate on the table if you have any coding on your transactions that would help surface corporate action transactions for proper handling.

CORPORATE ACTION CHALLENGES:
- Can have adverse effect on performance without proper handling
- Require additional editing and special consideration
- Need special coding to identify corporate action transactions

RECOMMENDED APPROACH:
- Notify First Rate of any corporate action coding in your system
- Identify transaction codes that help surface corporate actions
- Document special handling requirements for corporate actions
- Work with implementation team to establish proper procedures

training-reference/Data_Management/Data_.title: Data Transmission Frequency
training-reference/Data_Management/Data_.content:
FREQUENCY OF TRANSMITTING ACCOUNTING DATA

MINIMUM FREQUENCY:
Data should be transmitted to First Rate at least on a monthly basis. The client may elect to transmit files more frequently due to the large volume of data associated with monthly processing. More frequent loading balances the process over the entire month and allows for pre-month-end auditing, which expedites the month-end process.

MONTH-TO-DATE PERFORMANCE REQUIREMENTS:
When month-to-date performance is required, all files must be transmitted to First Rate on a daily or weekly basis, such as:
- Portfolio information
- Cash balances
- Holdings
- Transactions
- Asset/price information

The transaction file could contain:
- All trades that settled since the prior transmission
- Any pending trades as of that day
- Transmission of data on the trade date is preferred

VOLUME CONSIDERATIONS:
For volume considerations alone, it is not necessary to transmit all files to First Rate. In order to reduce data volume, the transaction file would be required that contains only:
- Trades that settled since the prior transmission
- Any pending trades as of that day

TRANSACTION ADJUSTMENTS CHALLENGE:
The disadvantage to transmitting daily files as opposed to monthly files centers around transaction adjustments. During any given month, transactions are being entered, reviewed, and adjusted. A monthly extract can usually wash out various adjustments so only the final transaction is delivered to First Rate.

However, with daily transmission:
- If a transaction is captured on a particular day and adjusted later in the month
- We need enough information to identify and modify the original trade
- Consider how far into a new month you want to permit backdating and adjustments

BACKDATING CONSIDERATIONS:
- No standard for backdating updates
- Client may choose to backdate through:
  * First three business days
  * End of first week
  * Middle of the month
  * Up to the end of the following month
- Prior month's performance is subject to change each time data is loaded that permits backdating

REQUIREMENTS FOR ADJUSTED TRANSACTIONS:
1. The transaction must be sent to First Rate each time it is adjusted
2. A unique field should be placed on adjusted transactions so they can be handled in a different manner
3. The transactions must all have unique transaction identifiers so the original and adjusted transaction can be matched up in the First Rate system and the adjusted transaction applied

training-reference/Data_Management/Evalu.title: Evaluate Accounting Data and Repair
training-reference/Data_Management/Evalu.content:
EVALUATE ACCOUNTING DATA AND REPAIR EXCEPTIONS

This process represents a critical quality control step in the First Rate Performance workflow. After accounting data has been extracted and loaded, it must be thoroughly evaluated for accuracy and completeness before performance calculations can proceed.

EVALUATION PROCESS:
- Systematic review of loaded accounting data
- Identification of data quality issues
- Assessment of data completeness
- Validation of data integrity

EXCEPTION IDENTIFICATION:
- Data inconsistencies
- Missing required information
- Unusual or outlier values
- Balance reconciliation issues

REPAIR ACTIVITIES:
- Correction of identified data issues
- Resolution of balance discrepancies
- Adjustment of incorrect values
- Completion of missing data elements

QUALITY ASSURANCE:
- Verification of repairs
- Validation of corrected data
- Confirmation of data readiness for processing
- Documentation of changes made

This evaluation and repair process ensures that only high-quality, accurate data proceeds to the performance calculation stage, maintaining the integrity of the entire performance measurement process.

training-reference/Data_Management/Extra.title: Extract and Load Bridge
training-reference/Data_Management/Extra.content:
EXTRACT AND LOAD ACCOUNTING BRIDGE

This section refers to the detailed process of extracting data from client accounting systems and loading it into the First Rate Performance system. The extract and load process serves as the critical bridge between the client's accounting data and the performance measurement system.

KEY COMPONENTS:
- Data extraction from client accounting systems
- Data transformation to First Rate formats
- Data loading into performance system
- Quality validation during the process

CRITICAL BRIDGE FUNCTION:
- Connects client accounting systems to First Rate Performance
- Ensures data integrity during transfer
- Transforms data to appropriate formats
- Validates data quality before processing

PROCESS IMPORTANCE:
- Foundation for all subsequent performance calculations
- Critical for data accuracy and reliability
- Requires careful mapping of client data fields
- Essential for successful performance measurement

This bridge process is fundamental to the entire performance measurement workflow, ensuring that client data is properly captured, transformed, and loaded for accurate performance analysis.

training-reference/Data_Management/Final.title: Final Audited Performance Release
training-reference/Data_Management/Final.content:
RELEASE OF FINAL AUDITED PRIOR MONTH PERFORMANCE

PERFORMANCE EXPECTATIONS:
With a good extract/interface process that supplies accurate accounting data, the client can usually expect 90 – 95% of their portfolios to be available for preliminary viewing within 24 hours of receipt of the last files (i.e., prices and backdated trades) necessary to compute the prior month performance.

RESOLUTION TIMELINE:
- It can take anywhere from another one to seven business days to resolve all the issues for the remaining portfolios
- Typically, another 2 – 3% of the portfolios are released on the 4th and 5th business days based on global accounting repairs

PORTFOLIO STATUS CODES:
First Rate Performance displays a status code on each portfolio to indicate its status for prior month performance:
- PRELIMINARY STATUS: Initially, portfolios that pass all exception reports will show Preliminary status until global audits are completed
- FINAL STATUS: After global audits are completed, portfolios are adjusted to display Final status
- IN REVIEW STATUS: If a portfolio appears on an exception report, it will show an In Review status until all corrections are made or the return is deemed correct

RELEASE METHODS:
Typically, First Rate releases preliminary portfolios immediately to Advisor and the portfolios being reviewed are made available as they are scrubbed and finalized. The availability of these portfolios in Advisor is controlled by a report date that may be set according to the method of releasing accounts:
- Release as returns are reviewed/revised
- Release altogether
- Other

PERFORMANCE METRICS:
- 90-95% of portfolios available within 24 hours
- Remaining portfolios resolved within 1-7 business days
- Additional 2-3% released on days 4-5 based on global repairs

KEY FACTORS:
- Quality of extract/interface process
- Accuracy of accounting data
- Timeliness of final files (prices and backdated trades)
- Effectiveness of global accounting repairs

training-reference/Data_Management/Finan.title: Financial Fields and Transaction Effects
training-reference/Data_Management/Finan.content:
FINANCIAL FIELDS AND TRANSACTION EFFECTS

FINANCIAL FIELDS
Depending on the accounting system, multiple financial fields are sometimes used to perform different accounting activities. Examples of these are the Principal, Income, and Carry amounts. In order to get the correct performance effect, we may need to handle the income separately as income to the portfolio or we might need to net the two fields together to get the appropriate performance effect.

TRANSACTION EFFECT
Part of the discussion regarding transactions is specific to the accounting effect of the transaction. For example, First Rate needs to know if the sign for a transaction is positive or negative and if there is an impact to un-invested cash. You may also need to indicate if the sign for the transaction is assigned by some other process.

KEY CONSIDERATIONS:
- Multiple financial fields may be used for different accounting activities
- Principal, Income, and Carry amounts may need special handling
- Transaction signs (positive/negative) must be clearly defined
- Impact to un-invested cash must be identified
- Sign assignment processes need to be documented

training-reference/Data_Management/Incep.title: Inception Month Performance
training-reference/Data_Management/Incep.content:
INCEPTION MONTH FOR PERFORMANCE

First Rate Performance will attempt to compute a rate of return on the first month data is received for a portfolio. You have the option of using a utility within First Rate to ignore the first partial month of data and use the first full month to be the portfolio inception.

INCEPTION MONTH CALCULATION:
- The return computed during the first month makes use of the flow timing and actual flows available during that month
- Performance results vary based on whether this portfolio is actually being funded during this month, at the end of the month, or the beginning

HELPFUL REPORTS FOR INCEPTION REVIEW:
- Rate Warnings audit research report
- New and Closed Portfolios standard report
- Asset Summary Review audit research report

VALID INCEPTION MONTH CRITERIA:
- A non-zero return
- A plugged return from a historical conversion
- During implementation, you may provide a file of inception dates to use that will override any inception date that First Rate might compute

KEY CONSIDERATIONS:
- First partial month can be ignored if desired
- Flow timing affects performance results
- Funding timing (beginning, middle, end of month) impacts calculations
- Override capabilities available during implementation

training-reference/Data_Management/Light.title: Lights Out Processing
training-reference/Data_Management/Light.content:
LIGHTS OUT PROCESSING AND REPORTING

First Rate Professional provides Lights Out batch processing and reporting that can be defined and scheduled to run at a specified time, either as a background process, or locally from the user's workstation. Processing in the background allows the user to continue with other functions within the Professional application.

LIGHTS OUT UTILITY FUNCTIONS:
The Lights Out utility lets you perform a variety of data and administrative functions, such as:
- Loading historical data, inception dates, sector inception dates, or differential return sectors
- Building performance, benchmarks, and composites
- Flagging audit exceptions
- Maintaining prices and accruals
- Performing extracts
- Assigning portfolio, sector, and benchmark report colors
- Viewing status reports and processing logs

SECURITY AND ACCESS CONTROL:
- Security access assigned by your First Rate Performance administrator determines the functions available to individual users
- Your administrator may also restrict certain date ranges and portfolios from Lights Out processing, based upon global and portfolio freeze dates
- Your First Rate implementation team will discuss your Lights Out reporting options

NUMBER OF USERS:
To provide you with the best training and processing experience, The First Rate implementation team will ask you about the number and location of your users. We will need this information to:
- Accurately scale your system environment
- Define your remote access needs
- Provide secure access to your reports

KEY BENEFITS:
- Background processing allows continued use of application
- Scheduled processing for efficiency
- Comprehensive functionality for data management
- Secure, controlled access to features
- Status monitoring and logging capabilities

training-reference/Data_Management/Overv.title: Overview
training-reference/Data_Management/Overv.content:
DATA MANAGEMENT OVERVIEW

The First Rate Performance system is an extremely flexible tool for measuring and reporting investment performance. In order to customize the solution to meet your needs, the First Rate implementation team will conduct a detailed discussion in order to better understand your unique needs and assist in making the initial set up decisions.

The following is a brief description of each of the items you must consider as you determine your specific performance measurement configuration.

DETAIL AND SUMMARY DATA

Data is stored for your performance data at both summary and detail levels. Summary level allows you to store values, accruals, income, positive and negative flows, positive and negative factors, and unit value returns for your sectors and categories. Detail level allows you to store the holdings and transactions by asset for each portfolio. This is an important consideration when you need to view and make corrections to your performance data.

We recommend keeping detail level data for a specified period of time, but if your reporting requirements permit, you may consider purging older detail information for purposes of database management.

KEY CONSIDERATIONS:
- Summary Level: Values, accruals, income, flows, factors, unit value returns
- Detail Level: Holdings and transactions by asset for each portfolio
- Recommended: Keep detail level data for specified period
- Optional: Purge older detail information for database management

training-reference/Data_Management/Proce.title: Processing Flow Overview
training-reference/Data_Management/Proce.content:
OVERVIEW PROCESSING FLOW

The processing flow diagram shows the systematic approach First Rate uses to process client data and produce performance results. The flow consists of several interconnected processes:

MAIN PROCESSING STEPS:

1. EXTRACT (1.0)
   - Client Accounting System feeds into Extract process
   - Produces Extract Files

2. LOAD ACCOUNTING DATA (2.0)
   - Takes Extract Files as input
   - Loads data into the performance system

3. EVALUATE ACCOUNTING EXCEPTIONS (3.0)
   - Reviews loaded data for issues
   - Identifies problems requiring attention

4. REPAIR AND RELEASE EXCEPTION ACCOUNTS (4.0)
   - Addresses identified exceptions
   - Prepares accounts for processing

5. BUILD PERFORMANCE (5.0)
   - Central processing hub
   - Computes performance calculations
   - Connects to multiple audit and review processes

6. FLAG EXCEPTION ACCOUNTS (6.0)
   - Identifies accounts requiring review
   - Flags for further analysis

7. PERFORMANCE REPORTING
   - Final output of the process
   - Delivers results to end users

PROCESS CHARACTERISTICS:
- Systematic, step-by-step approach
- Multiple quality control checkpoints
- Exception handling at various stages
- Interconnected processes with feedback loops
- Focus on data quality and accuracy

QUALITY ASSURANCE INTEGRATION:
- Exception identification and handling
- Multiple review and audit points
- Repair and correction capabilities
- Performance validation steps

This processing flow ensures that client data is systematically processed, reviewed, and validated before final performance reporting is generated.

training-reference/Data_Management/Retur.title: Return Review Process
training-reference/Data_Management/Retur.content:
RETURN REVIEW

Returns are reviewed as follows:

1. RETURN REVIEW
   The Rate Distribution and Rate Warnings reports are used when reviewing monthly return quality after accounting data has been repaired

2. RETURN TOLERANCES
   The tighter the tolerance level, the longer it takes to review returns because more valid returns appear on the report and must be reviewed. Conversely, there may be some returns that pass tolerance, but are not technically correct.
   
   First Rate recommends that rate tolerances start at:
   - 7% above or below a market index for equities
   - 3% above or below for a fixed income index
   - 0.5% above or below for a short-term index

3. TOLERANCE PACKAGES
   First Rate lets you create and assign tolerance packages to individual portfolios or portfolio groups. These packages establish an acceptable high and low return range for selected sectors, categories, and currencies relative to a benchmark or a flat return (i.e., no benchmark assigned).
   
   Features:
   - Portfolios with rates of return falling outside the established tolerance appear on the Rate Warnings report
   - Allows you to spot exceptions
   - Requires each portfolio's investment objective to be passed to First Rate
   - Appropriate benchmarks selected for processing
   - If this is not available, a default tolerance package will be applied

4. PRICING SOURCE
   First Rate uses the client's prices exclusively as the pricing source. While we do not verify every price separately, reviewing the Price Warnings and Invalid Transaction Principal reports may reveal:
   - Invalid price for receipts/deliveries being valued
   - Corporate actions
   - Capital gains issue

5. PERFORMANCE SEGMENT RETURN REVIEW
   
   OPTION 1: All segment/category returns are reviewed for reasonableness
   - In order to implement this option, a benchmark must be assigned for each performance segment that adequately reflects the returns that should be expected and reflects the tolerance for each portfolio
   - The Rate Distribution report can give you an indication of the data quality without benchmarks
   
   OPTION 2: First Rate computes as many performance segments as desired and reviews them at a high level for reasonableness
   - An example might involve Total Equity, Total Fixed, Total Cash, and Cash Equivalents

RECOMMENDED TOLERANCE LEVELS:
- Equities: 7% above or below market index
- Fixed Income: 3% above or below index
- Short-term: 0.5% above or below index

KEY TOOLS:
- Rate Distribution report
- Rate Warnings report
- Price Warnings report
- Invalid Transaction Principal report
- Tolerance packages for portfolio groups

training-reference/Data_Management/Rever.title: Reversals
training-reference/Data_Management/Rever.content:
REVERSALS

First Rate will need to understand your method of handling reversals during the measurement period. It is important that these kinds of transactions are handled properly on the extract.

REVERSAL HANDLING RULES:
- We do not want reversals suppressed from the extract if the original transaction was in a prior period
- During a single extract period, an original transaction and reversal could be:
  * Suppressed altogether, OR
  * Both could be sent and handled properly in the performance system
- Additional discussions on reversals will be part of the implementation process

KEY CONSIDERATIONS:
- Proper handling of reversals is critical for accurate performance measurement
- Treatment varies depending on timing of original transaction vs. reversal
- Implementation team will work with client to establish reversal handling procedures

training-reference/Data_Management/Stand.title: Standard Auditing Process
training-reference/Data_Management/Stand.content:
FIRST RATE'S STANDARD AUDITING PROCESS

As a practice, all revisions to accounting data are confirmed by the client and noted in our audit logs at the time of repair or in the monthly archived copy of the audit reports that describe the issue. Over time, the client and performance analyst may agree on a set of standard audit practices in order to expedite delivery and avoid case-by-case approval. These will be noted in the client's checklist.

AUDIT DOCUMENTATION:
- All revisions to accounting data are confirmed by the client
- Revisions are noted in audit logs at the time of repair
- Monthly archived copy of audit reports describes the issue
- Standard audit practices may be agreed upon over time
- Standard practices are noted in the client's checklist

PROCESS EVOLUTION:
- Initial approach: Case-by-case approval for all revisions
- Evolved approach: Standard audit practices for common issues
- Goal: Expedite delivery while maintaining accuracy
- Method: Client-analyst agreement on standard practices

BENEFITS OF STANDARD PRACTICES:
- Expedited delivery of performance results
- Reduced need for case-by-case approval
- Consistent handling of common issues
- Maintained audit trail and documentation
- Improved client-analyst efficiency

KEY PRINCIPLES:
- Client confirmation required for all data revisions
- Comprehensive audit trail maintenance
- Evolution toward standard practices for efficiency
- Balance between speed and accuracy
- Clear documentation of approved procedures

training-reference/Data_Management/Trans.title: Transaction Codes
training-reference/Data_Management/Trans.content:
TRANSACTION CODES

Transaction Codes are unique to each accounting system that interfaces with First Rate Performance. The code(s) we use to determine performance may require a single field or may involve multiple fields from the accounting system. If there are major transaction-type and sub-type fields in your accounting system, these fields determine if a transaction should be handled as a purchase or perhaps a contribution. The First Rate implementation team will conduct a detailed discussion in order to map the codes to handle your unique situation.

First Rate Performance comes with pre-defined transaction identifier code (T_IDENT) values in the filter values table. You can edit these values through the Data Map -> Table Values Editor. To add transaction code (T_CODE) values for each identifier, use the Data Map -> Transaction Codes editor to update the transaction code table. Transaction identifier values do not display in the transaction code table unless they have at least one valid T_CODE.

TRANSACTION IDENTIFIER TYPES:

Identifier Code | Description | Flows
---|---|---
Contribution/Cash Receipt | New dollars to portfolio | Contribution – Positive flow to Total Fund and Cash; Cash Receipt – Positive flow to Cash and negative flow to Sector
Distribution/Cash Withdrawal | Dollars leaving portfolio | Distribution – Negative flow to Total Fund and Cash; Cash Withdrawal – Negative flow to Cash and positive flow to Sector
Dividends | Dollars paid by corporations to individuals | Positive flow to Income Principal and Interest, positive flow to Cash Principal and Interest
Fee | Dollars paid for investment management, performance-based services, etc. | Negative flow to Total Fund and negative flow to Cash
Free Receipt | New assets to portfolio | Positive flow to Total Fund and Sector
Free Delivery | Assets leaving portfolio | Negative flow to Total Fund and Sector
Income Received/Purchased | New dollars to portfolio from investment or dollars leaving portfolio for asset purchase | Positive flow to Income and Cash
Interest | Income earned on deposits held in investment vehicles | Positive flow to Principal and Interest Income, positive flow to Principal and Interest Cash
Null | Disregard transaction | No performance impacts
Purchase | Dollars moving from cash to asset in portfolio | Positive flow to Sector, negative flow to Cash
Sale/Maturity | Dollars moving from asset to cash | Negative flow to Sector, positive flow to Cash
Stock Split | For balance units only, no performance | [No performance impact]

IMPORTANT CONSIDERATIONS:
- Any 'general use' transaction codes used for cash or asset-related activities that are difficult to classify will be potential issues when processing data
- Each transaction should serve only a single performance purpose
- We require enough information from the system to identify that single effect in order to get the best performance result without scrubbing
- The client is responsible for identifying to First Rate all the possible codes and identifiers that should distinguish different types of transactions for performance purposes

training-reference/Data_Management/Troub.title: Troubleshooting Returns
training-reference/Data_Management/Troub.content:
TROUBLESHOOTING RETURNS

CAUSE OF INACCURATE RETURNS AND SOLUTIONS:

1. ACCRUALS OUT OF SYNC WITH INCOME PAYMENTS
   Cause: Accrual is not computed and the income payment is late
   Solution: Recommend global accrual change to adjust month-end accrual amount when possible

2. LATE PAYING INCOME
   Cause: Income that is received after underlying asset is sold. Usually a problem in a sector that has sold out of all its holdings or holds very few assets
   Solutions:
   - Leave as-is, because placing the income in the month it occurred restates published returns
   - Alternative is for extract not to send this income
   - Accounting system is source for income payment information
   - __________ is source for income payment information

3. INCORRECT COUPON AND DIVIDEND PAYMENT INFORMATION
   Cause: This condition impacts daily sub-period returns. Current month dividend information for equities and the ex-dividend date along with coupon rate for fixed income. The monthly security characteristics table should contain the coupon rate for all fixed income assets. If not present in the characteristics table, then Yield will be used from the security table
   Solutions:
   - Accounting system is source for income payment information
   - __________ is source for income payment information

4. INCORRECT PRICES OR LACK OF DAILY PRICES ON ASSETS
   Cause: The security file must contain the correct factor: .01 for fixed income assets, any value other than .01 for equity assets. This impacts ability to revalue portfolio for large flows or daily performance. First Rate relies on the accounting system or other system of record to supply accurate pricing data
   Solutions:
   - Final pricing file available on ___ day after month-end
   - Hedge Fund pricing and use of prior period and restatement
   - Other pricing issues

5. INCORRECTLY VALUED ASSET RECEIPTS AND DELIVERIES
   Cause: These need to be valued and representative of the value of the asset in the month the receipt/delivery occurs. If the book/carry value of the asset is provided to First Rate, the result will be a large gain or loss for the period and skewed return
   Solutions:
   - Client posts all receipts/deliveries with current value
   - Client will create extract change that performs valuation
   - Client requests First Rate to revalue using the following pricing scheme

6. CAPITAL GAINS POSTING ON THE DAY FOLLOWING A PRICE DROP
   Cause: This is a problem for daily portfolios and if it happens at the end of a month it could be a problem for monthly portfolios too
   Solutions:
   - Move the day the transaction occurs in First Rate Performance
   - Change the day of the price change

7. CORPORATE ACTION SPIN-OFFS
   Cause: Corporate Action Spin-offs that result in part of the old asset funding an asset in a new performance segment. If the trades aren't present to fund the new asset and divest a portion of the old asset, there are performance issues
   Solutions:
   - Client will pass trades that reduce position in old asset and fund new asset
   - Client requests that First Rate create custom program that creates trades based on file of corporate action cusips. Detail in Business analysis phase

8. CUSIP CHANGES IDS AND SECTORS
   Cause: The process we use should reflect what is on the trust system. In many cases, no transactions are utilized for the removal of the old asset and the arrival of the new asset
   Solutions:
   - Client will provide Free Delivery transaction at value for the old asset and a Free Receipt transaction for the new asset using the same value for that day
   - Client requests First Rate create custom program that creates delivery and receipt transactions

9. INCOME OR FEE REBATES NOT TIED TO AN ASSET
   Cause: This impacts Total Fund and will not be attributed to the manager or asset earning income
   Solutions:
   - Assign security ID to transaction on extract
   - Let it post as income to Cash/Total Fund

10. UNITS WITHOUT VALUE OR VALUE WITH ZERO UNITS ON A HOLDING
    Cause: Both conditions could be indicator of inaccurate performance
    Solutions:
    - Send prices and have program written to revalue assets accordingly
    - Test extract to ensure that problem does not exist

training-reference/Performance/00_Perfor.title: 00 Performance Section Overview
training-reference/Performance/00_Perfor.content:
PERFORMANCE SECTION OVERVIEW

Section Summary
===============

The Performance section of the First Rate training manual spans pages 29-48 (corresponding to files page_32.txt to page_51.txt) and provides comprehensive coverage of performance measurement methodologies, calculation requirements, and system configurations.

Main Topics Covered
==================

1. Performance Calculation Methods
   - Modified Dietz formula and its applications
   - Time-weighted and money-weighted returns
   - Unit Value Returns (UVR) and linking methodologies
   - Special handling for short sells and liability returns

2. GIPS Compliance Requirements
   - Base offering compliance standards
   - Data requirements for GIPS-compliant computations
   - Significant flow handling and revaluation requirements
   - Beyond GIPS capabilities including daily and point-to-point returns

3. Daily and Point-to-Point Returns
   - Daily accrual value calculations for cash equivalents
   - Rules and hierarchy for daily factors
   - First Rate Advisor reporting capabilities
   - Daily performance advantages and disadvantages

4. Return Calculation Frequency
   - Four frequency options: Monthly (M), Daily (D), Significant Flow (F), Total Fund Only Significant Flow (T)
   - Data requirements for each frequency type
   - Processing implications and billing considerations

5. Performance Schema and Sectors
   - Sector and category hierarchy
   - Multiple sector mapping capabilities
   - Total Managed vs Excluded Assets handling
   - Directed and excluded asset methodologies

6. Gross-of-Fees and Net-of-Fees
   - GIPS standards recommendations
   - Automated fee calculation support
   - Basis point fee management
   - Custom fee implementation options

7. After-Tax Performance
   - Federal, state, and local tax rate applications
   - Tax rate calculation formulas
   - Asset taxability identification requirements
   - Setup process for after-tax performance

8. Multi-Currency Performance
   - Five currency scenarios supported
   - Enhanced reporting capabilities
   - Implementation requirements and consultation process

Key Formulas and Calculations
============================

Modified Dietz Formula:
rDietz = [EMV + EA + I - [(1-PF)P + (1-NF)N]] / [BMV + BA + (PF)P + (NF)N]

Anticipated Tax Rate Formula:
AnticipatedTaxRate = FedRate + [StateRate * (1 – FedRate)] + [LocalRate * (1 – FedRate)]

Technical Specifications
=======================

Database Tables Referenced:
- FRPAIR (Portfolio Demographics)
- FRPIPP (Daily Performance)
- FRPSECTR (Sector Performance)
- FRPSICP (Sector Inception)
- FRPSEC (Asset Table)
- FRPTRAN (Transaction Table)
- FRPTX (Tax Table)
- FRPINDXD (Index Daily Returns)

System Programs:
- Build Daily Performance
- Build Performance
- Load Sector Inception (FRPSICP_LOAD)
- Price Maintenance Program
- Lights Out

Configuration Options:
- Portfolio-level return calculation frequency flags
- Sector-level skip significant flow settings
- Asset-level, sector-level, and global-level factor settings
- Tax offset sector configurations
- Basis point fee rules

Implementation Considerations
============================

Data Requirements:
- Daily prices for all held assets
- Income payment information for accrual estimation
- Dividend dates and rates for equity assets
- Coupon rates and factors for fixed income assets
- Complete transaction synchronization
- Month-to-date holdings information

Best Practices:
- Inflows set to '0' (beginning of day)
- Outflows set to '1' (end of day)
- Fixed assets price factor set to 0.01
- Monthly queries on fixed price assets
- Proper factor setting hierarchy maintenance

Performance Optimization:
- Significant flow tolerance typically set to 10%
- UVR tolerance exceptions reporting at 20
- Monthly vs daily processing decisions
- Point-to-point reporting requirements
- Fee spreading across applicable time periods

Page References
===============

Original Training Manual Pages: 29-48
Corresponding Text Files: page_32.txt through page_51.txt
Corresponding Images: training-32.png through training-51.png

Files Created in Performance Directory:
- 00_Performance_Section_Overview.txt (this file)
- 01_Performance_Calculation_Methods.txt
- 02_GIPS_Compliance_Requirements.txt
- 03_Daily_and_Point_to_Point_Returns.txt
- 04_Return_Calculation_Frequency.txt
- 05_Performance_Schema_and_Sectors.txt
- 06_Gross_and_Net_of_Fees.txt
- 07_After_Tax_Performance.txt
- 08_Multi_Currency_Performance.txt
- 09_Performance_Visual_References.txt

training-reference/Performance/01_Perfor.title: 01 Performance Calculation Methods
training-reference/Performance/01_Perfor.content:
PERFORMANCE CALCULATION METHODS

Performance Calculation Overview
===============================

First Rate provides both time- and money-weighted rates of return using the Modified Dietz formula:

Modified Dietz Formula:
rDietz = [EMV + EA + I - [(1-PF)P + (1-NF)N]] / [BMV + BA + (PF)P + (NF)N]

Where:
- EMV is the ending market value
- EA is the ending accrual amount
- I is the income amount (included when calculating sector performance; excluded when calculating Total Fund performance)
- PF is the positive factor
- P is the positive flows
- NF is the negative factor
- N is the negative flows
- BMV is the beginning market value
- BA is the beginning accrual amount

Special Handling for Short Sells:
When computing the Modified Dietz for a sector, if the numerator is less than or equal to zero and the denominator is less than zero, defined as a short sell, the performance measurement suite adjusts the Unit Value Return (UVR) to provide an inverted rate of return.

Unit Value Returns (UVR):
This formula is the computation that provides UVRs that can then be linked for a time-weighted rate of return for the specified period. A money-weighted rate of return uses the Modified Dietz as the beginning estimate for the Internal Rate of Return (IRR) calculation over multi-month periods.

Monthly Return Derivation:
First Rate Advisor reports show monthly returns and the result of linking the one month returns over longer periods (i.e., one year, three years, inception-to-date, etc.). Monthly returns can be derived in two ways:

1. Use the Modified Dietz for the entire month
2. Create a monthly return by revaluing the portfolio each day and linking individual daily returns using the Modified Dietz

In months where there are insignificant flows, the monthly return is the same, so it is unnecessary to revalue each portfolio every day. Additionally, as long as First Rate receives daily prices, it is possible to retrieve a derived daily return through First Rate Advisor for monthly calculations.

Performance Calculation Frequency:
Given that the Modified Dietz is the basis for performance, there is additional information regarding the frequency of the calculation that should be considered as the First Rate Performance suite is deployed for your organization.

Liability Returns (Negative Value Returns):
