When computing the Modified Dietz for an option sector, if the numerator is less than or equal to zero and the denominator is less than zero, First Rate Professional adjusts the UVR to provide an inverted rate of return.

Regular short sells are assets with negative values and First Rate calculates them just like a normal asset by inverting the returns. No special action is required for them, unless they are placed in their own sectors, which is recommended.

training-reference/Performance/02_GIPS_C.title: 02 GIPS Compliance Requirements
training-reference/Performance/02_GIPS_C.content:
GIPS COMPLIANCE REQUIREMENTS

GIPS Compliance – Base Offering
===============================

To maintain claims of GIPS-compliant computations (which really does not mean an institution is GIPS compliant; it is the methodology of reporting returns that determines compliance), firms must revalue portfolios and compute returns within the month when a significant flow occurs.

Data Requirements for GIPS Compliance:
In order for First Rate to accomplish the revaluations necessary for returns, the following data are required:

1. Daily prices passed at least once a month
2. Income payment information for fixed and equity assets in order to estimate accruals

Minimum Return Computation:
At a minimum, returns will be computed using the monthly return and will be made up of linked daily returns only when there is a significant flow during the month. The most common significant flow tolerance is 10%, but First Rate allows for a user-defined tolerance.

Beyond GIPS – Daily and Point-to-Point Returns
============================================

Enhanced Performance Capabilities:
Once the extracts are transmitting the daily price file, even if it is only once a month, First Rate can offer an additional level of daily performance and can be selected at the account level. With the receipt of a daily price file, First Rate can code a portfolio to value it each day throughout the prior month, build and store daily returns, and subsequently link the returns for a one month return.

Point-to-Point Return Capability:
As long as daily returns are calculated, the end user can access Point-to-Point returns through First Rate Advisor's drill-down reports. For example, the client could see a return from Jan 19th, 2013 to Sept 2nd, 2013. This granularity can be accomplished with no additional passes of data and would occur after we receive the monthly extract with the previous month's prices.

Month-to-Date Returns:
If the accounting system can send nightly extracts, First Rate has the additional ability to show a month-to-date return for the prior business day. As stated above, the month-to-date return is either going to be a Modified Dietz (if there are no significant flows) or it will be the result of linking daily returns up through the last night if the portfolio is daily or has a significant flow.

Additional Effort Required:
Month-to-date returns do require additional effort. They require:
- The receipt of more frequent data
- The client's understanding of preliminary returns
- More system resources

Inception-to-Date Returns:
First Rate Performance provides the ability to report inception-to-date returns based on either selected portfolio or sector inception dates, i.e. the first date the portfolio or sector was available for performance.

Portfolio Inception Returns:
In order to provide portfolio inception returns, portfolio and composite inception dates must be loaded in the portfolio demographics table (FRPAIR_ICPDATED).

Sector Inception Returns:
To provide sector inception returns, the Load Sector Inception program (FRPSICP_LOAD) must be run to populate the sector inception table (FRPSICP) with sector inception dates based on data in the sector performance table (FRPSECTR) and the daily performance table (FRPIPP). This program allows you to specify if you wish to include partial periods as the inception or set the inception date to the first full month of data.

training-reference/Performance/03_Daily_.title: 03 Daily and Point to Point Returns
training-reference/Performance/03_Daily_.content:
DAILY AND POINT-TO-POINT RETURNS

Daily Accrual Value for Cash Equivalent Positions
=================================================

Cash Returns Calculation:
First Rate Performance correctly calculates cash returns, which can be distorted if daily accruals are not calculated. First Rate calculates daily returns for uninvested cash because that information is required for a Total Fund return. The system has the option to retain the return and use the linked return or discard it.

Accrual Estimation:
If assets are flagged properly, the daily accrual module will estimate an accrual based on a variety of income factors.

Short-Term Investment Fund (STIF) Requirements:
First Rate requires a daily mil rate for Short-Term Investment Fund (STIF) to accurately calculate the cash equivalent portion of the portfolio. Cash equivalents typically have a variable rate on a daily basis.

Daily Rate Storage:
We store daily rates on the daily performance table (FRPIPP) for every day of the month, including weekends and holidays. Computed daily accrual rates are not stored. The daily accrual from the accounting system is stored (FRPIPP) but not used for computations.

Skip Significant Flow Setting:
By setting the short term sector to 'Skip Significant Flow', at the end of the month dividing income earned by the average balance provides an accurate return.

Rules on Daily Factors
======================

Factor Setting Hierarchy:
Factor settings on daily portfolios are honored in this order:
1. Asset level
2. Sector level
3. Global variable level

Factor Setting Process:
First Rate Performance's Build Daily Performance program reads the setting at the asset level first, the sector second, and the global variable level third to determine which daily factor setting to use. 

Best Practice Guidelines:
- If factors are maintained at the global level, the other levels should be set to null
- If they are maintained at the sector level, the asset level should be set to null
- It is important to be sure all levels are set correctly

Current Best Practice Settings:
- Inflows set to '0' (beginning of day)
- Outflows set to '1' (end of day)

Build Performance Changes:
Build Performance used to plug factors regardless of when there was a 90% sellout. This has changed and now Build Performance honors the global variable (GLVAR) that is available in the Administration Library.

UVR Tolerance Exception Reporting:
The UVR Tolerance Exceptions report can be driven by setting the Daily Asset UVR Tolerance in the GLVAR. One suggestion is to set this to 20 and run the UVR Tolerance Exceptions report for all daily clients.

Fixed Asset Price Factor Requirements:
All Fixed (FX) assets should be set to a Price Factor of 0.01. If the portfolios are Daily, daily performance will use the price multiplied by the factor to compute performance. A bad factor will cause bad returns. It is helpful to run a query monthly on fixed price assets to ensure that they are set to 0.01.

First Rate Advisor Reports and Daily Performance
===============================================

Monthly Reporting:
Accounts with daily performance have linked daily returns, but Advisor reports those returns only for month-end. The only exception is that during the current calendar month, a report can be generated month to date, with the appropriate date reflected on the report.

Daily Return Access:
Actual daily returns are available through Advisor drill-down reports and can be run in Excel or PDF output.

More on Daily Performance
=========================

Daily Module Default Settings:
The Daily module, by default, assumes a beginning-of-day transaction with a Flow Weighting Factor = 1.0. First Rate Performance is able to control the flow weighting factor at the following levels: Asset, Sector, and Global.

Day Factor Settings:
The day factor can be set/changed to:
- Beginning of day (1.0)
- Middle of day (0.5)
- End of day (0.0)

Mutual Fund Example:
Mutual Funds are an example where the default beginning of day (BOD) weighting may not be desirable. Due to their pricing, it could be argued that an end of day (EOD) assumption is more accurate.

Buy-in/Sell-out Tolerance:
The Buy-in/Sell-out percentage tolerance will override the Flow Weighting Factor setting and set a "buy" to 1.0 and "sell" to 0.0. This tolerance, by default, is set to 90% and can be changed.

Daily Return Calculation Method Usage:

ALLOWED WITH:
Sectors/Categories:
- Includes sectors/categories with negative values
- Includes the uninvested cash sector in the categories' rates of return, even if that sector is flagged to 'Skip Significant Flow Check' in Professional
- Excludes sectors/categories flagged to 'Skip Significant Flow Check' in Professional
- Excludes sectors/categories with plugged values. To change a Daily performance return, edit the detail-level data in First Rate Professional
- Excludes Net of Tax sectors

Composites:
- All underlying portfolios must be set to Daily in order to use the Daily Composite build

Policy Benchmarks/Blended Benchmarks:
- Daily returns must exist for constituent benchmarks (in FRPINDXD) and the portfolio (in FRPIPP)

CANNOT BE USED WITH:
- Cash Diversification Allocation rates of return

Daily Performance Advantages and Disadvantages:
When deciding whether or not to use the Daily return calculation method, your First Rate Performance Analyst considers the following advantages and disadvantages. Daily returns are considered to be a more accurate measure for managers because the impact of cash flows is confined to the day on which the flow occurs. However, there are certain data requirements that are a prerequisite for accurate performance.

Data Review Requirements:
Your asset data should be reviewed to identify any potential issues that might arise when calculating daily returns, and then updated accordingly.

Frequency Change Impact:
Once you change a portfolio's return calculation frequency, that change applies only to future builds, although you may rebuild prior data using the new return calculation frequency. To rebuild prior data, you must have the required information, as well as the previous month's holding information for portfolios with non-zero beginning values.

Rebuild Limitations:
You can rebuild daily performance only for periods after the global freeze date set by your administrator or the portfolio-specific freeze date.

Performance Build Process:
Each time you build performance, all daily performance return data is deleted for selected portfolios and processing periods. Daily performance returns are then rebuilt based on the current Return Calculation Frequency setting. This also ensures that trades that come in with dates prior to the current date are re-summarized for significant flow return frequencies.

Implementation Consultation:
During the Implementation Decisions phase, you will have discussions with your First Rate implementation team and your Performance Analyst to determine if daily returns are appropriate.

training-reference/Performance/04_Return.title: 04 Return Calculation Frequency
training-reference/Performance/04_Return.content:
RETURN CALCULATION FREQUENCY

Frequency Options
================

First Rate provides multiple valuation frequency options by using four available portfolio-level return calculation frequency flags:

M – Monthly
- Builds monthly performance for the portfolio

D – Daily
- Builds daily performance for the portfolio regardless of significant flows

F – Significant Flow
- Builds daily performance for the portfolio if any sector has a significant flow that is not flagged to skip the significant flow check

T – Total Fund Only Significant Flow
- Builds daily performance for the portfolio only if the Total Fund sector has a significant flow

Monthly Frequency
================

Monthly Option Requirements:
The Monthly option requires a monthly extract from your accounting system to be loaded, processed, and stored as monthly data.

Monthly Approach:
This approach disregards any significant flows or daily revaluations. You may elect to post the majority of your portfolios using monthly valuation, while those portfolios that require a more frequent valuation can be run more frequently.

Minimum Processing:
At a minimum, all portfolios must be processed on a monthly cycle.

Daily Frequency
==============

Daily Performance Definition:
Daily Performance is a very broad term that merits additional definition. It is important to understand that daily performance has implications depending on how often files are transmitted in addition to the types of daily returns available.

Daily Performance Variations:
This brief explanation describes the variations and highlights the requirements for each.

Modified Dietz Usage:
First Rate Performance returns are typically calculated using the Modified Dietz calculation method. You may choose to allow First Rate Performance to also use a daily calculation to generate more accurate monthly returns by revaluing the portfolio on a daily basis.

Point-to-Point Capability:
The drilldown capability in First Rate Performance for portfolios set to Daily allows for Point-to-Point returns to be viewed via the Summary page in First Rate Advisor.

Daily Flag ('D') Behavior:
Portfolios set to 'D' will build using the Daily module and store data for Point-to-Point reporting. All sectors flagged as "Skip Significant Flow Check" will maintain the monthly UVRs and the other sectors will have the UVR replaced with the linked daily UVR.

Billing Implications:
Portfolios flagged as "D" are assumed to be in need of Point-to-Point reporting because they will have daily performance no matter what the flows are, and therefore will be billed as such.

Net Transaction Total:
The net transaction total includes contributions, distributions, free receipts, free deliveries, sales and purchases flows. It will not include dividend and interest income receipts and capital gain distributions flows.

Significant Flow (Large Cash Flow)
=================================

Significant Flow Definition:
First Rate Performance defines a significant or large cash flow as the percentage of the net positive or negative transaction total for the sector and date to the previous period's ending value for the sector. The most common selection is a flow greater than 10% although the actual threshold percentage used for your institution can be customized.

Sector Inclusion/Exclusion:
First Rate allows clients to choose sectors that should not be included in the evaluation for significant flows. Otherwise, if a significant flow methodology is elected, all sectors will be included in the significant flow test.

Portfolio-Level Processing:
If any one of these valid sectors has a significant flow, the entire portfolio will be computed using the daily module for that month. The daily module replaces the monthly UVR with the linked daily UVR for applicable sectors.

Total Fund Only Significant Flow
===============================

Total Fund Level Evaluation:
Significant or large cash flows are evaluated at the Total Fund level only. If the flows exceed the tolerance established, then the entire portfolio is computed using the daily module for that month and valid sectors have their return replaced by the linked daily unit value return.

Daily Return Data Requirements
=============================

The following data must exist within First Rate Performance for the application to successfully calculate rates of return using the Daily method:

1. Daily Prices:
   - The price file should contain prices for all assets held for each trading day of the month
   - If any prices are missing, the Price Maintenance Program must be run in Lights Out

2. Dividend Dates/Rates:
   - The asset characteristics table must contain the ex-dividend dates and rates for the period being processed
   - This information is used to estimate the accrual within the month for equity assets

3. Coupon Rates/Factor:
   - The asset characteristics table should contain the annual coupon rate for all held Fixed Income assets
   - If not present in the characteristics table, then the annual coupon rate will be used from the asset table
   - The asset table must also contain the correct pricing factor (.01 for fixed assets, any value other than .01 for equity assets) and the accrual type code to determine the daycount convention
   - This information is used to estimate the accrual within the month for fixed assets

4. Daily Transactions:
   - The transaction table must contain all transactions for the period being processed
   - These transactions must be synchronized with the month-to-date holding information
   - Out of balance portfolios produce erroneous daily performance results

5. Month-to-Date Holdings:
   - The holdings table must contain the month-to-date positions for the period being processed
   - These holdings must be synchronized with the daily transaction information
   - Out of balance portfolios produce erroneous results
   - Because the daily performance build process uses asset-level information to get prior values, holdings must be present for the prior month if the beginning value is not zero
   - This differs from the monthly build process, which uses the sector return table to establish the beginning value

training-reference/Performance/05_Perfor.title: 05 Performance Schema and Sectors
training-reference/Performance/05_Perfor.content:
PERFORMANCE SCHEMA AND SPECIAL RETURN CALCULATIONS

Performance Sectors and Categories
==================================

Performance Calculation Hierarchy:
Although performance is calculated at the security level for certain reports, most reporting uses performance sectors and categories. Sectors and categories serve as a hierarchy of asset classes that can be compared with specific benchmarks on performance reports.

Sector Definition:
Sectors are the lowest grouping for which detailed data and rates of return are calculated and stored. The financial data for sectors are then summarized—or rolled up—into higher level asset classes (categories), as defined by the client during implementation.

Category Roll-up:
The financial information in each sector can be rolled up in multiple ways, creating higher level asset classes, thereby providing flexibility in performance reporting.

Example Hierarchy:
For example, you may want to break Cash and Equivalents down into Money Market Funds, Treasury Bills, Certificates of Deposit, etc. Cash and Equivalents would be considered a category, while Money Market Funds, Treasury Bills, and Certificates of Deposit would be considered sectors.

Sector/Category Assignments:
A First Rate Performance table contains the sector/category assignments for every asset, position, and transaction. First Rate Advisor's Sector Schema report provides an easy way to view this arrangement of sectors and corresponding categories.

Multiple Sector Mappings:
Additionally, First Rate Performance supports assigning assets to up to three different sector mappings for more flexible reporting, such as by industry segmentation, style, or other characteristic.

Adding New Sectors:
You may add new sectors and categories within any schema at any time to be used from that point forward.

Example of Multiple Sector Assignments:
For example, the fictitious asset Acmecom could have the following alternate sector assignments:

Sector Assignment 1: Consumer Discretionary (12)
Sector Assignment 2: Corporate (43H2)
Sector Assignment 3: Equity Other (25H3)

Data Loading and Processing:
Once the extract files are loaded into the First Rate system, the detail data loads to the appropriate sector and then the sectors are rolled up into the appropriate categories. All categories and sectors are built automatically during the process.

Schema Design Considerations:
When designing your classification scheme, determine how you want to report performance most often. Your First Rate representative will guide you through the process to create the schema that supports your reporting requirements.

Total Managed vs Excluded Assets
===============================

Non-Discretionary Asset Challenge:
At First Rate, we understand that many advisors are asked by their clients to report on non-discretionary assets that may have trading restrictions. Advisors agree to report on these assets for the benefit of the client, although these assets are not in the manager's direct control.

Total Managed Return:
Therefore, it is important for the manager to separate managed asset performance from non-managed assets in order to distinguish the value of its management responsibilities. First Rate refers to discretionary managed assets as the Total Managed return.

Two Methods for Handling Non-Discretionary Assets:

1. Directed Assets:
   - This method keeps the asset within the portfolio
   - It is measured in a performance segment that can be segregated from other managed assets
   - Creates a Total Managed performance number
   - Total Managed and Total Fund can be reported to demonstrate both managed and non-managed asset performance

2. Excluded Assets:
   - This election excludes the asset from the portfolio
   - The asset would never be included for performance in Total Fund or Total Managed
   - Any transactions involving these assets would be counted as cash contributions and withdrawals

Implementation Options:
Either of these solutions can be implemented globally across the entire database for an asset or dictated on a portfolio-by-portfolio basis.

Directed Asset Setup:
You will need to set up one or more sectors to accommodate directed assets. For example, all directed assets could be assigned to a category called 'Directed' or they could be further defined as 'Directed Equity', 'Directed Fixed Income', etc.

Unmanaged Sector Configuration:
Sectors can be defined to isolate the non-managed assets by using the Sector Calc ID flag of U – Unmanaged. When the 'Build Sector 01TM' global option is set to Y in First Rate Administration, Build Performance creates a new Total Managed (01TM) sector that excludes sectors flagged as U.

Reporting Capability:
This allows you to report on the entire portfolio's performance while excluding non-managed assets.

Implementation Support:
The First Rate implementation team will work with you to identify and earmark managed and non-managed assets for reporting.

Visual Reference - Sector Schema Report Table (training-42.png):
==============================================================

The Sector Schema report provides a hierarchical view of the performance sector structure. The report displays:

Report Header:
- Report Name: Sector Schema
- Sector Direct
- Run Date/Time: 11/01/2011 17:39:53
- Shows "306 of 306 records, Page 1 of 1"

Table Structure:
The report shows a hierarchical table with the following columns:

- Most Level Categories
- Sectors

Key Elements Displayed:
- TX: TOTAL FIXED INCOME (expandable category)
- ST: TOTAL CASH & CASH EQUIVALENTS (expandable category)
  - CT: Total Cash Equivalent Tax
  - ST: TOTAL CASH & CASH EQUIVALENTS
  - Subcategories showing sector codes:
    - 02: Cash Uninvested
    - 03: Money Market Funds
    - 05: CASH & EQUIVALENTS
    - 06: Treasury Bills

This hierarchical structure demonstrates how sectors (the lowest level) roll up into categories, providing the flexible reporting structure described in the documentation. The table allows users to see the complete sector/category mapping for all assets in the system.

training-reference/Performance/06_Gross_.title: 06 Gross and Net of Fees
training-reference/Performance/06_Gross_.content:
GROSS-OF-FEES AND NET-OF-FEES PERFORMANCE

GIPS Standards and Fee Reporting
===============================

GIPS Recommendations:
The GIPS standards recommend that performance be reported "gross-of-fees" when reporting to prospective clients—that is, before management fees are deducted—as opposed to "net-of-fees"—after fees are deducted.

Fee Structure Impact:
Since a manager's fee is often based on a percentage of the assets (asset-based fee) instead of the absolute performance of the portfolio against a benchmark (performance-based fee), returns computed net-of-fees will inadvertently vary depending on the portfolio size.

Automated Support:
Both returns can be supported in an automated fashion for all portfolios, as long as the investment management fee or performance-based fee is distinguishable as a separate transaction.

Standard Return Type:
The standard for First Rate returns is gross-of-fees. However, First Rate computes net-of-fee returns at the Total Fund level.

Gross-of-Fee vs Net-of-Fee Mechanics
===================================

Gross-of-Fee Return:
The gross-of-fee return reflects the reduction in cash (portfolio value) and the transaction that justifies that reduction in cash (which is a flat performance event when the flow reduces the value).

Net-of-Fee Return:
The net-of-fee keeps the reduction in cash value (portfolio value) but removes the effect of the flow which reduces the return creating a net-of-fee return.

Reporting Options:
You can report gross-of-fees or net-of-fees for the composite. You have the same selection opportunity for the portfolio.

Fee Timing Recommendations:
For the smoothest monthly performance results, First Rate recommends a single annual or quarterly fee be spread across the months it relates to. If this is not possible, then the client must be prepared to accept dips in performance when the fee is assessed.

Custom Fee Implementations
=========================

Sector Level Net-of-Fee Returns:
On a custom basis, net-of-fee returns can be computed at a more detailed sector level if the necessary conditions exist to support the computations and data storage.

External Fee Data Integration:
Multiple types of data feeds containing fee data can be loaded into First Rate. If the client provides annual fees from an external system along with the applicable time period, First Rate has the ability to recalculate performance net-of-fees.

External Fee Data Disadvantage:
The disadvantage to this method is that prior performance numbers would be restated for fees that were received late.

Basis Point Fees
===============

Fee Management Options:
First Rate Performance provides different ways to manage net-of-fee performance. Fees can be written to a default fee offset sector that rolls up into a single Total Fund net-of-fee category. Or, multiple fee sectors can be created, such as one for performance-based fees and another for management fees.

Multiple Fee Categories:
These fee sectors may each roll up into categories like Total Fund Net of Performance Fees or Total Fund Net of Management Fees.

Static Basis Point Fee Calculation:
Alternately, net-of-fee performance can be computed by applying static basis point fees to portfolio/sector combinations.

Basis Point Fee Configuration:
For example, First Rate Professional lets you specify:
- The portfolio's gross-of-fees sector (e.g., Total Fund)
- Net-of-fees sector (e.g., Total Fund Net of Fees)
- Annual basis point fee (e.g., 1.55% per year or 155 basis points)
- Activation date

Basis Point Fee Storage:
These basis point rules are stored in the basis point fee table and activated on demand.

Build Performance Process:
When build performance is run, all net-of-fee performance will be built. Net-of-fee returns based on basis point fees have a sector return calculation frequency of 'B' and overwrite net-of-fee returns based on transaction fees if they exist.

Special Parameter Option:
If you wish to compute net-of-fee returns based on basis point fees without running build performance, a special parameter may be added to the Lights Out program.

Zero Basis Point Fee Feature:
Also note that if a basis point fee of zero is entered, the return of the gross sector will be written to the net sector. This feature can be used to copy returns from one sector/category to another.

training-reference/Performance/07_After_.title: 07 After Tax Performance
training-reference/Performance/07_After_.content:
AFTER-TAX PERFORMANCE

After-Tax Performance Calculation
=================================

Calculation Scope:
First Rate Performance can calculate performance net of federal, state, and local tax rates for Total Fund, Total Equity, Total Fixed, Total Cash and Equivalents, as well as any number of lower-level sectors and/or categories, such as Domestic Equity, International Equity, etc.

Federal Tax Only Option:
The system also includes a portfolio-level option to calculate returns net of federal taxes only.

Tax Amount Computation:
Tax amounts are computed using the short- and long-term gains/losses received from the accounting system for sale transactions and the income earned on taxable assets each month. Income earned includes actual income received and the change in accrued income for the period.

Tax Rate Application:
First Rate Performance applies the defined short-term and long-term tax rates to the income earned and gains/losses.

Universal After-Tax Coverage:
The system creates after-tax performance returns for every open portfolio, thereby ensuring that after-tax information exists for every segment of every portfolio, avoiding confusion about which portfolios have after-tax performance.

Report Selection:
When running performance reports, the user selects the net-of-tax categories to include or exclude from the presentation.

Tax Rate Application Schedule
============================

The following tax rates are applied:

Qualified Dividend-Paying Assets:
- Before 2003: Short-Term Anticipated Tax Rate
- January – April 2003: 15% Federal Tax Rate (hard-coded in the application)
- After April 2003: Long-Term Anticipated Tax Rate

Non-Qualified Dividend-Paying Assets:
- Short-Term Anticipated Tax Rate

Other Income Earned:
- Short-Term Anticipated Tax Rate

Short-Term Gains/Losses:
- Short-Term Anticipated Tax Rate

Long-Term Gains/Losses:
- Long-Term Anticipated Tax Rate

Anticipated Tax Rate Calculation
===============================

The Anticipated Long-Term and Short-Term Tax Rates are derived from the following calculation:

AnticipatedTaxRate = FedRate + [StateRate * (1 – FedRate)] + [LocalRate * (1 – FedRate)]

Where:
- FedRate (Federal Rate) is the long- or short-term federal tax rate from the portfolio table (FRPAIR) if a portfolio-specific rate is recorded, or the tax table (FRPTX)
- StateRate (State Rate) is the long- or short-term state tax rate from the portfolio table (FRPAIR) if a portfolio-specific rate is recorded, or the tax table (FRPTX)
- LocalRate (Local Rate) is the long- or short-term local tax rate from the portfolio table (FRPAIR) if a portfolio-specific rate is recorded. Local rates are not stored on the tax table

Data Requirements for After-Tax Performance
==========================================

Asset Identification:
Assets must be identified for their taxability status (e.g., taxable, non-taxable, qualified dividend-paying, or municipal bond).

Gains and Losses:
Short-term and long-term gains and losses must be received and loaded.

Tax Rates:
Federal or state tax rates must be loaded into the tax table or overridden at the portfolio level. Local tax rates reside only at the portfolio level.

Asset Qualification Requirements:
As part of the implementation process, you will need to identify the asset types that qualify as dividend-paying assets based on The Jobs and Growth Tax Reconciliation Act of 2003. Please provide a complete list of minor asset types that qualify as dividend-paying assets.

Data Loading Guidelines
======================

Taxable Asset Coding:
Taxable assets should be populated with Y (Yes) or D (Dividend) in the taxable field (TAXABLEI) of the asset table (FRPSEC); non-taxable assets should be populated with N (No); Municipal Bonds should be coded with M (Muni Bond).

Gains and Losses Loading:
Gains and losses should be loaded into the short-term gain/loss (SHRTGAIN) and long-term gain/loss (LONGGAIN) fields on the transaction table (FRPTRAN).

Tax Rate Loading:
Tax rates should be loaded in the short (MAXSHORT) and long (MAXLONG) tax rate fields in the tax table (FRPTX) or overridden in the portfolio demographics table (FRPAIR) by populating the federal/state long-term or short-term tax rate fields (TXRATE1 – TXRATE4). Local tax rates (if desired) must be loaded in the local long-term or short-term tax rate fields (TXRATE5 – TXRATE6) of the portfolio demographics table (FRPAIR) only.

After-Tax Performance Setup Process
==================================

Tax Offset Sector Creation:
First Rate Performance can calculate after-tax performance based on federal, state, and local tax rates. Gains and losses are totaled for each asset in a sector with a tax offset sector, including income earned for taxable assets. Tax rates are applied to these gains/losses and income, and the calculated tax is then applied to the positive flow field of the appropriate tax offset sector.

Performance Build Impact:
When Build Performance is run, these additional flows have the effect of degrading performance by the amount of the tax, providing an after-tax return.

Setup Steps:

1. Create or edit the following tax offset sectors using Data Map -> Sector/Category:
   - 1F — Total Fund tax offset sector
   - 9F — Default tax offset sector. Do not assign taxes to sector 9F — the application automatically assigns taxes not assigned to any other tax offset sector to sector 9F
   - Other tax offset sectors — Equity, fixed, and cash tax offset sectors. Any available sector assignments can be used; only 1F and 9F are reserved

2. Enter a tax offset sector ID in the Tax Offset field of each taxable sector using Data Map -> Sector/Category

3. Create the after-tax roll-up categories using Data Map -> Sector/Category. After-tax roll-up categories include the appropriate underlying sectors, at least one tax offset sector, and itself

4. Edit asset tax settings using Data Map -> Assets:
   a) Flag assets in the Taxable field as follows:
      - Y (Yes): Asset is taxable
      - N (No): Asset's income is non-taxable. If an asset is coded as non-taxable, only the income is non-taxable. Gains and losses are taxable for all assets at the federal level
      - D (US Dividend): Eligible assets are taxable at a reduced dividend tax rate
      - M (Muni Bond): Asset's income is taxable only if the asset's state ID does not match the portfolio's state tax code

   b) For all assets flagged as 'M' in the Taxable field, record a State ID code

5. Add monthly federal and state tax rates to the tax table (FRPTX) using Data Map -> Tax Rates. Use the two-digit state ID code for state tax rates or FD for federal tax rates

6. Edit portfolio-specific Tax Settings in the portfolio table (FRPAIR) using Process -> Edit Demographics:
   - Set the Tax Federal Only drop-down list to Yes to indicate that after-tax performance should use only federal tax rates for this portfolio
   - Set this value to No to indicate that after-tax performance should use both federal and state tax rates for this portfolio
   - Record long- and short-term federal, state, and local tax rates as needed
   - Record the State Tax Code for the portfolio

7. Edit short- and long-term gains/losses and income received using Process -> Edit Transactions

Tax Rate Override Rules:
If you specify a federal or state tax rate for a portfolio in the FRPAIR table, either by using Process -> Edit Demographics or when loading data, the portfolio uses that tax rate instead of the one in the FRPTX table. To force the portfolio to use the FRPTX table's tax rate, clear the FRPAIR table's tax rate fields for that portfolio. Local tax rates reside only on the portfolio table.

Visual Reference - Tax Impact Report Table (training-46.png):
============================================================

The Tax Impact Report demonstrates the after-tax performance calculation in action. The report shows:

Report Header:
- Tax Impact Report
- Name of Account 110111111991990

This report demonstrates how the anticipated tax rates are applied to different types of income and gains to calculate the comprehensive after-tax performance impact.

training-reference/Performance/08_Multi_.title: 08 Multi Currency Performance
training-reference/Performance/08_Multi_.content:
MULTI-CURRENCY PERFORMANCE

Multi-Currency Performance Scenarios
====================================

First Rate provides the ability to calculate performance using multiple currencies in the following scenarios:

1. Buying a Domestic Asset with Base Currency Cash
2. Buying a Foreign Asset with Base Currency Cash
3. Buying a Domestic Asset with Foreign Currency Cash
4. Buying a Foreign Asset with the Same Foreign Currency Cash
5. Buying a Foreign Asset with a Different Foreign Currency Cash

Enhanced Reporting Capabilities
==============================

When multi-currency performance is enabled, First Rate Advisor makes available a number of enhanced reports.

Implementation Requirements
==========================

If multi-currency performance is required in your organization, please inform your First Rate implementation team. The team will interview you to confirm your requirements and explain the data and configuration needed for calculating multi-currency performance.

Note: This section indicates that multi-currency performance is available but requires specific implementation consultation and configuration. The detailed technical specifications and data requirements would be provided during the implementation process with the First Rate team.

training-reference/Reporting/00_Reportin.title: 00 Reporting Section Overview
training-reference/Reporting/00_Reportin.content:
REPORTING SECTION OVERVIEW

This section covers the comprehensive reporting capabilities of First Rate Advisor, including report creation, management, and customization features.

KEY TOPICS COVERED:
1. Report creation and management
2. Portfolio grouping strategies
3. Time and sector selections
4. Managed reporting features
5. Branding and customization options

MAIN CONTENT AREAS:
- Reporting Overview (types of reports available)
- Creating Groups (portfolio groups, report groups, etc.)
- Quick Select Portfolio Groups
- Graph Color Assignment
- Report Date Options Management
- Time and Sector Selections
- Tiered Reporting
- Managed Reporting
- Branding Options

PAGES COVERED: 78-82 (Training Manual pages 81-85)

training-reference/Reporting/01_Reportin.title: 01 Reporting Overview
training-reference/Reporting/01_Reportin.content:
REPORTING OVERVIEW

At First Rate, we understand that the reports you deliver provide evidence of your service and illustrate your investment story to your clients. First Rate Advisor has over ninety reports available for reviewing, analyzing, and presenting performance information.

TYPES OF REPORTS AVAILABLE:

1. PERFORMANCE REPORTS
   - Over 70 classic reports that are part of First Rate Advisor's standard offering
   - Standard reports for performance analysis and presentation

2. ANALYST REPORTS
   - Package of premium reports for back-office analysts
   - Available as a separately negotiated license
   - Specialized reports for detailed analysis

3. ONPOINT REPORTS
   - Personalized reports consisting of base sub-report components
   - Various templates available
   - Client-branded theme options
   - Created through First Rate Administration's wizard-driven interface
   - Can be run on an ad-hoc basis in First Rate Advisor
   - Can be organized into report groups and scheduled to run for specific portfolio groups

PERFORMANCE GRANULARITY:
First Rate's reports provide different levels of performance granularity to meet your client needs. Using Advisor's decision-making guide, the Field Guide to Reporting, the First Rate implementation team will review the available Advisor reports with you to confirm which reports you want to use and the data necessary to support them.

IMPLEMENTATION PROCESS:
On a functional level, running reports is the culmination of many decisions made during the Advisor setup process. During the implementation process, you will have the opportunity to determine how to customize the Advisor application for optimal use.

FLEXIBLE FEATURES INCLUDE:
- Creating groups for reporting purposes
- Creating Quick Select portfolio groups
- Assigning portfolio, sector, and benchmark graph colors
- Managing report date options
- Making time period and sector selections
- Using Tiered Reporting and/or Managed Reporting

training-reference/Reporting/02_Creating.title: 02 Creating Groups
training-reference/Reporting/02_Creating.content:
CREATING GROUPS

First Rate Performance lets you set up groups to help you process performance or run reports. Groups are collections of items used when reviewing Quick View data or running reports. 

INITIAL SETUP REQUIREMENT:
When you initially log onto the application, you must first set up at least one portfolio group before running reports or reviewing Quick View data.

ACCESSING GROUP SETUP:
Use the Personalize tab in First Rate Advisor to set up groups. Depending on your security privileges, you may be able to add and maintain the following types of groups:

TYPES OF GROUPS:

1. PORTFOLIO GROUPS
   - Access: Personalize -> My Portfolios
   - Purpose: Manage your assigned portfolios into folder groups
   - Usage: These groups of portfolios appear on Advisor's Summary and Run Reports pages

2. REPORT GROUPS
   - Access: Personalize -> My Reports
   - Purpose: Add, remove, and update groups of reports that are run on the Run Reports page
   - Benefits: The report group remembers which reports to run, the sort order, and the various options and sectors so you do not have to re-set your preferences each time to run a report
   - Result: Better consistency and productivity

3. REPORT OPTION GROUPS
   - Access: Personalize -> Custom Options
   - Purpose: Add, remove, and update report option groups that are used to set up report groups
   - Function: Option groups specify how many periods you wish to report on, which reporting frequencies, which sector schemas, and so forth
   - Availability: Option groups appear on the Run Reports and My Reports pages

4. SECTOR AND BENCHMARK GROUPS
   - Access: Personalize -> Custom Benchmarks or Custom Sectors
   - Purpose: Add and manage sector or benchmark groups that are used to set up report groups
   - Availability: Sector and Benchmark groups appear on the Run Reports My Reports pages

5. REPORT OPTION 2 GROUPS
   - Access: Secondary report option groups appear in the Custom Report Options 2 window on the Run Reports and My Reports pages
   - Access Method: Accessible from the hyperlinked report name
   - Purpose: Establish additional run-time parameters
   - IMPORTANT WARNING: Care should be taken so that the default for all other users does not change; instead, create a new RO2 group to make changes for your own reports

6. SECTOR BENCHMARK SORT GROUPS
   - Access: Personalize -> Sector Benchmark Sort
   - Purpose: Manage how sectors and benchmarks are sorted when running reports or viewing Quick View data
   - Availability: Sector benchmark sort groups appear in the Custom Report Options 2 window on the Run Reports and My Reports pages

GROUP FLEXIBILITY:
Groups provide a lot of flexibility. For example, when adding a group of reports, you can add the same report twice, assigning each instance of the report a different group of report options.

training-reference/Reporting/03_Quick_Se.title: 03 Quick Select Portfolio Groups
training-reference/Reporting/03_Quick_Se.content:
CREATING QUICK SELECT PORTFOLIO GROUPS

PURPOSE AND BENEFITS:
Advisor's Quick Select Portfolio Groups let you create adhoc portfolio groups from the Summary page without using Personalize -> My Portfolios. This improves the speed of group building and data retrieval.

DISPLAY LOCATION:
Once populated, these Quick Select groups appear at the top of your list of portfolio groups on both the Summary and Run Reports page.

ACCESS CONTROL:
Access to this feature is controlled by your administrator.

QUICK SELECT OPTIONS:
The Quick Select drop-down menu provides the following portfolio options:

1. QUICK SELECT SINGLE PORTFOLIO
   - Function: Select a single portfolio by name or ID
   - Use Case: When you need to run reports for just one specific portfolio

2. QUICK SELECT STATIC LIST
   - Function: Select multiple portfolios by ID
   - Use Case: When you have a predetermined list of specific portfolios to include

3. QUICK SELECT DYNAMIC LIST
   - Function: Select multiple portfolios by filter values
   - Use Case: When you want to select portfolios based on certain criteria or attributes

4. MY COMPOSITES
   - Function: Create and build permanent or temporary composites from existing portfolio groups
   - Use Case: When you need to combine portfolios into composites for reporting purposes

ADVANTAGES:
- Faster group creation process
- No need to use the Personalize interface
- Immediate availability for reporting
- Flexible selection methods (single, static list, dynamic list, composites)
- Appears prominently at the top of portfolio group lists

training-reference/Reporting/04_Graph_Co.title: 04 Graph Color Assignment
training-reference/Reporting/04_Graph_Co.content:
ASSIGNING GRAPH COLORS

OVERVIEW:
First Rate Professional lets you customize the graph colors assigned to portfolios, sectors, and benchmarks for reporting purposes.

COLOR STORAGE LOCATIONS:
These selections are stored in the color fields of the portfolio demographics and sector/benchmark tables and utilized by Advisor when running presentations.

ADDITIONAL COLOR SETTINGS:
First Rate Administration also lets you select graph colors for data that is not sector/benchmark specific, such as:
- Portfolio data
- Model data
- The All Other group

These color selections are stored in the global variables table.

DEFAULT COLOR BEHAVIOR:
If colors are not specified in the above tables, First Rate Performance uses the default colors from the system-wide color scheme.

AUTOMATIC COLOR ASSIGNMENT:
You may also run a color assignment program from Lights Out to automatically generate colors for portfolios, sectors, and benchmarks that have missing colors.

IMPORTANT NOTES ABOUT AUTOMATIC COLOR ASSIGNMENT:
- This program is intended to be run once or for large quantities of missing colors
- NOT intended to be run on a regular basis
- Reason: New missing colors will always be assigned the first colors from the file
- Best practice: Use for initial setup or bulk assignments only

COLOR ASSIGNMENT WORKFLOW:
1. Manual Assignment (Preferred):
   - Set colors individually through First Rate Professional
   - Set colors through First Rate Administration for non-sector/benchmark specific data
   - Store in appropriate database tables

2. Automatic Assignment (Bulk Setup):
   - Run color assignment program from Lights Out
   - Use for missing colors in bulk
   - Understand that subsequent runs will reuse first colors from file

3. Default Fallback:
   - System uses default colors when no specific colors are assigned
   - Maintains consistency across the application

training-reference/Reporting/05_Report_D.title: 05 Report Date Options Management
training-reference/Reporting/05_Report_D.content:
MANAGING REPORT DATE OPTIONS

OVERVIEW:
First Rate Performance provides several global options that allow you to manage how report dates are displayed and reported.

KEY DATE MANAGEMENT OPTIONS:

1. REPORT DATE OPTIONS
   - Function: Controls whether the From date on presentation and drill-down reports uses the last day of the prior month or the first day of the month
   - Impact: Affects how date ranges are displayed on reports
   - Choice: Last day of prior month OR first day of current month

2. LAST LOAD DATE
   - Function: Controls the last As of Date permitted on the Quick View, Run Reports, and Managed Reporting screens
   - Basis: Based upon the date of the last data load
   - Example: If the last load date is 11/15/11, First Rate Performance will allow:
     * As of Dates from 11/1/11 through 11/15/11
     * Any month-end date for the previous month (i.e., 10/31/11, 09/30/11, etc.)
   - Purpose: Ensures reports only use data that has been loaded into the system

3. DATE FORMAT ELECTIONS
   - Function: Controls whether the application, presentation, and drill-down reports use specific date formats
   - Format Options:
     * MM/DD/YYYY format
     * DD/MM/YYYY format
   - Calendar Phrase Options:
     * 'As of Date'
     * 'As at Date'
   - Impact: Affects how dates appear throughout the application and reports

4. BUILD FREEZE DATES
   - Portfolio Build Freeze Date: 
     * Limits how far back performance can be built for individual portfolios
     * Portfolio-specific limitation
   - Global Build Freeze Date:
     * Limits how far back any performance data can be built
     * System-wide limitation
     * Overrides individual portfolio settings
   - Purpose: Prevents building performance data beyond certain historical dates

IMPLEMENTATION CONSIDERATIONS:
- These are global settings that affect the entire system
- Changes impact all users and all reports
- Should be configured during initial setup based on business requirements
- Date format elections should match regional preferences and client expectations

training-reference/Reporting/06_Time_and.title: 06 Time and Sector Selections
training-reference/Reporting/06_Time_and.content:
MAKING TIME AND SECTOR SELECTIONS

DYNAMIC USER INTERFACE:
First Rate Advisor has a dynamic user interface that allows you to produce reports on an adhoc or scheduled basis.

REPORT FLEXIBILITY:
Most reports can be selected to run at a sector or category level and for user-defined time periods.

IMPLEMENTATION SUPPORT:
During the implementation process, your team will explain all flexible options and determine the best definition and roll-out for your organization.

KEY CAPABILITIES:

1. SECTOR-LEVEL REPORTING
   - Run reports at specific sector levels
   - Category-level reporting options
   - Flexible sector selection for different report types

2. TIME PERIOD SELECTION
   - User-defined time periods
   - Custom date ranges
   - Flexible reporting frequencies

3. ADHOC REPORTING
   - On-demand report generation
   - Immediate report creation with custom parameters
   - Dynamic selection of time periods and sectors

4. SCHEDULED REPORTING
   - Automated report generation
   - Predetermined time periods and sectors
   - Consistent reporting cycles

CUSTOMIZATION BENEFITS:
- Tailor reports to specific client needs
- Adjust reporting granularity based on requirements
- Flexible time period analysis
- Sector-specific performance review
- Category-based reporting options

IMPLEMENTATION PROCESS:
- Implementation team reviews all available options
- Determines optimal configuration for your organization
- Explains flexible features and capabilities
- Establishes best practices for report configuration
- Provides training on dynamic interface usage

OPERATIONAL ADVANTAGES:
- Reduces manual report configuration time
- Increases reporting consistency
- Enables responsive client service
- Supports various analytical needs
- Accommodates different reporting requirements

training-reference/Reporting/07_Tiered_R.title: 07 Tiered Reporting
training-reference/Reporting/07_Tiered_R.content:
USING TIERED REPORTING

PURPOSE:
First Rate offers Tiered Reporting to clients who are interested in providing differing levels of report access to their customers.

HOW TIERED REPORTING WORKS:
When tiered reporting is enabled, tier levels are assigned to:
- Sectors
- Categories  
- Reports
- Portfolios

ACCESS CONTROL MECHANISM:
When your First Rate Advisor users run reports, portfolios are restricted to reports and sectors/categories that are within the portfolio's assigned tier level.

TIER LEVEL RESTRICTIONS:
- Portfolios can only access reports at or below their assigned tier level
- Sectors and categories are similarly restricted by tier level
- This creates a hierarchical access control system

BUSINESS USE CASES:
- Providing different service levels to different client types
- Restricting sensitive information based on client tier
- Creating premium reporting features for higher-tier clients
- Segmenting reporting capabilities by client relationship level

IMPLEMENTATION PROCESS:
If tiered reporting interests you, please inform your First Rate implementation team.

CONFIGURATION REQUIREMENTS:
- Tier levels must be assigned to all relevant components
- Sectors require tier level assignments
- Categories require tier level assignments
- Reports require tier level assignments
- Portfolios require tier level assignments

OPERATIONAL BENEFITS:
- Automated access control
- Consistent tier-based restrictions
- Reduced manual oversight of report access
- Scalable client service differentiation
- Protection of sensitive reporting features

CONSIDERATIONS:
- Requires careful planning of tier structure
- All components must be properly classified
- Changes to tier assignments affect user access immediately
- Training required for administrators managing tier assignments

training-reference/Reporting/08_Managed_.title: 08 Managed Reporting
training-reference/Reporting/08_Managed_.content:
USING MANAGED REPORTING

PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
While the Summary and Run Reports pages provide access to portfolio information in drill-down and presentation reports, the Managed Reporting page provides volume reporting for large numbers of portfolios.

KEY CAPABILITIES:

1. PORTFOLIO AND REPORT GROUP ASSOCIATIONS
   - With authorization, users can associate report and portfolio groups
   - Save these associations for use later
   - Can use associations with other user's groups
   - Enables consistent reporting across multiple users

2. SPECIALIZED PORTFOLIO GROUPS
   - The portfolio groups used in managed reporting are specific to managed reporting
   - Do not appear on the Summary and Run Reports pages
   - You can still use regular portfolio groups with managed reporting
   - Provides separation between managed reporting and standard reporting

3. GRANULAR SECURITY CONTROLS
   - Security at several levels to control access to managed reporting output
   - Tools for building managed reporting groups
   - Access control for other user's groups
   - Comprehensive authorization management

OPERATIONAL FEATURES:

1. VOLUME REPORTING
   - Designed for large numbers of portfolios
   - Efficient processing of bulk report generation
   - Suitable for institutional-level reporting needs

2. GROUP MANAGEMENT TOOLS
   - Tools for building managed reporting groups
   - Ability to manage and organize large portfolio sets
   - Streamlined group creation and maintenance

3. SHARED RESOURCE ACCESS
   - Use other user's groups when authorized
   - Share reporting configurations across the organization
   - Collaborative reporting environment

IMPLEMENTATION SUPPORT:
Your First Rate implementation team will discuss your Managed Reporting options during the setup process.

SECURITY CONSIDERATIONS:
- Multiple levels of access control
- Granular permissions for different users
- Protection of sensitive reporting output
- Controlled access to group building tools
- Authorization required for cross-user group access

BUSINESS BENEFITS:
- Scalable reporting for large portfolios
- Efficient bulk report processing
- Consistent reporting across multiple users
- Reduced manual report generation effort
- Centralized management of large-scale reporting needs

training-reference/Reporting/09_Branding.title: 09 Branding Options
training-reference/Reporting/09_Branding.content:
BRANDING

CUSTOM LOGO INTEGRATION:
You may elect to have your institution's logo appear on reports. Your First Rate representative can provide you with the exact image specifications.

MULTIPLE LOGO SUPPORT:
If there are multiple groups at your institution with different logo requirements, First Rate will work with you to develop a custom process to assign the logos properly.

APPLICATION NAME CUSTOMIZATION:
In addition to using custom logos in presentations, First Rate Advisor lets you change the application name itself by:

1. APPLICATION NAME REPLACEMENT
   - Replace all occurrences of "First Rate Advisor" with your application name
   - Exception: Copyright statements will retain "First Rate Advisor"
   - Comprehensive rebranding throughout the application

2. IMAGE REPLACEMENT
   - Replace all images in the application that include the application name
   - Replace all images in online help that include the application name
   - Ensures consistent branding across all visual elements

3. CUSTOM SPLASH PAGE
   - Use a splash page with custom content
   - Opportunity for additional branding and messaging
   - Personalized user experience from application startup

BRANDING LIMITATIONS:
Branding does not include:
- Changing First Rate Advisor's color theme
- Modifying style sheets
- Comprehensive visual theme changes

EXTENDED CUSTOMIZATION:
For information on customizing the product beyond standard branding options, please contact your First Rate representative.

IMPLEMENTATION PROCESS:
- Provide logo specifications to First Rate representative
- Determine application name changes
- Specify image replacement requirements
- Design custom splash page content
- Coordinate with First Rate for logo assignment processes

BUSINESS BENEFITS:
- Consistent institutional branding
- Professional appearance aligned with corporate identity
- Enhanced client recognition and trust
- Seamless integration with existing corporate materials
- Personalized user experience

TECHNICAL CONSIDERATIONS:
- Logo must meet specified image requirements
- Application name changes affect all interface elements
- Image replacement requires coordination with First Rate
- Custom splash page content must be provided
- Multiple logo scenarios require custom development
