training-reference/Terminology/Accrual.title: Accrual
training-reference/Terminology/Accrual.content:
Accrual

The amount of income, not yet received, that has been earned by an asset. For example, if a bond pays interest every six months, at the end of the third month you will have accrued half the interest for that period. If you sell the bond at that time, you receive the interest accrued through settle date as interest sold on the sale.

The accrual methodology used by an asset is determined by an asset's pricing factor (FACTOR) and accrual override (BETA) fields in the asset table (FRPSEC).

Accruals for fixed income assets are estimated based on the fraction of the annual coupon rate accrued during each period. This fraction is determined by the realized number of days in the period divided by the total number of days in the year. The total number of days in a year used in this calculation is typically 360, 365, or 366, depending on which day count convention is used. The day count convention for an asset is recorded in the accrual type field (ACCRTYPE) in the asset table (FRPSEC). This day count convention affects only the accrual estimation in First Rate Professional by specifying the number of days in the year.

• Equity accrual methodology – First Rate Performance calculates accruals based on the ex-dividend date (XDIVDT) and dividend rate (LASTDIV) fields on the asset characteristics table (FRPCHAR), as recorded on the Data Map > Assets screen in First Rate Professional.

• Fixed accrual methodology – First Rate Performance calculates accruals based on the Pay Date (SECDATE) and Annual Coupon Rate fields (COUPON) in the asset table (FRPSEC) if it exists, otherwise it uses the exdividend date (XDIVDT) and dividend rate (LASTDIV) fields on the asset characteristics table (FRPCHAR), as recorded on the Data Map -> Assets screen in First Rate Professional.

training-reference/Terminology/Accrual_M.title: Accrual Methodology
training-reference/Terminology/Accrual_M.content:
Accrual Methodology

Accruals are estimated for assets based on either a fixed income or equity methodology, as determined by the contents of each asset's pricing factor (FACTOR) and accrual override (BETA) fields in the asset table (FRPSEC):

• If the accrual override field has a value of .01, the asset uses the fixed income accrual methodology.
• If the accrual override field has a value of 1, the asset uses the equity accrual methodology.
• If the accrual override field does not have a value of .01 or 1, then:
  o If the pricing factor field has a value of .01, the asset uses the fixed income accrual methodology.
  o If the pricing factor field has a value of 1, the asset uses the equity accrual methodology.

training-reference/Terminology/Active_Re.title: Active Reporting Menu
training-reference/Terminology/Active_Re.content:
Active Reporting Menu

Active Reports include additional functions for choosing which data appears and how that data is displayed. Active Reports may include some or all of the following features:

• Sorting data by columns.
• Filtering data by column values.
• Hiding and un-hiding columns.
• Generating a pie, line, chart, bar, or scatter chart.
• Grouping data by a column.
• Creating a pivot table.
• Calculating the total number of records or distinct records.
• Expanding, collapsing, and flattening a report (called the accordion feature).
• Viewing reports and filters in the same window or in report tabs.
• Recording comments
• Sending the report via e-mail
• Exporting the report

Some Active Reporting features use ActiveX controls. If you receive a message noting that a feature requires ActiveX, please contact your administrator for assistance with adjusting your browser security settings.

For example, if you are viewing the Sector Schema report, you can follow these steps to view only equities:
1. Click the down arrow in the ID column heading, then choose Filter, Equals.
2. In the resulting Filter Selection screen, the filter should have the ID selected as the filter field and Equals selected as the filter action. In the remaining box, select EQ from the filter value drop-down list and click Filter.

training-reference/Terminology/Adjustmen.title: Adjustment Value Calculation
training-reference/Terminology/Adjustmen.content:
Adjustment Value Calculation

When a plugged UVR is encountered at the sector level, the application uses reverse algebra to compute an adjustment value for the ending market value in the Modified Dietz formula, as follows:

AdjustmentValue = ABS(UVR) * [(BMV + BA + (P(PF) + N(NF))] - [EMV + EA + I - P(1 - PF) + N(1 - NF)]

Where:
• BMV is the beginning market value.
• BA is the beginning accrual amount.
• I is the income amount (total fund sectors only).
• PF is the positive factor.
• P is the positive flows.
• NF is the negative factor.
• N is the negative flows.
• EA is the ending accrual amount.
• EMV is the ending market value.
• UVR is the unit value return.

Build performance does not compute an adjustment when building daily composites - note that build performance continues to compute an adjustment for UVRs for monthly composites to account for plugged UVRs.

training-reference/Terminology/Administr.title: Administrator Rights
training-reference/Terminology/Administr.content:
Administrator Rights

Security rights to perform administrative duties, such as assigning user accounts and passwords and establishing security access level.

training-reference/Terminology/Aggregate.title: Aggregate
training-reference/Terminology/Aggregate.content:
Aggregate

Any grouping of portfolios for performance. See composite.

training-reference/Terminology/Allocatio.title: Allocation Affect
training-reference/Terminology/Allocatio.content:
Allocation Affect

The difference between the fund's ending value and the value calculated at the Investment Manager's level. If the fund sponsor had invested in all of the managers and asset categories at the established policy allocations, then the Allocation Effects investment strategy's contribution would be zero.

training-reference/Terminology/Alpha.title: Alpha
training-reference/Terminology/Alpha.content:
Alpha

A measure of the difference between the actual performance of a portfolio and the performance that should have been achieved given the market's performance and the risk taken. This measure reveals the portfolio manager's success (positive alpha) or lack of success (negative alpha) in selecting securities and timing markets.

training-reference/Terminology/Annualize.title: Annualized Rate of Return
training-reference/Terminology/Annualize.content:
Annualized Rate of Return

An average return that 'backs out' the compounding that results from geometrically linking subperiod returns. The application annualizes time-weighted rates of return for periods greater than one year. Firms should not annualize returns for periods less than year. Annualization permits two returns measured over different periods of time to be compared to each other as follows:

UVR 12/n

Where n is the number of months being measured by the time-weighted return.

The annualization effect of partial months is calculated by dividing the number of days being reported by the number of days in the period. For example, annualizing the period of 16 January 2005 to 5 March 2006 results in the following annualization effects of partial months:

• For January, there are 16 days being reported (January 16 through 31) divided by the 31 days in January, or 16/31 = 0.51612…
• For March, there are 5 days being reported (March 1 through 5) divided by the 31 days in March, or 5/31 = 0.16129…

The numerator of the power is 12 and the denominator is 13.67741 (the number of full months from February 2005 through February 2006, or 13 months, plus the partial months, 0.51612 for January 2005 and 0.161290 for March 2006).

training-reference/Terminology/Audit.title: Audit
training-reference/Terminology/Audit.content:
Audit

The process of analyzing the exceptions to normal performance activity. A number of reports are supplied that assist in this process.

training-reference/Terminology/Average_M.title: Average Market
training-reference/Terminology/Average_M.content:
Average Market

The average market value for all portfolios at the end of a period derived from the following calculation:

Average Market = ΣEMV/n

Where:
• EMV is the ending market value of the asset.
• n is the number of portfolios.

The average value appears on the Management Annual Population Statistics and Management Quarterly Population reports.

training-reference/Terminology/Average_R.title: Average Rate
training-reference/Terminology/Average_R.content:
Average Rate

Equal-weighted annual return in which an equal-weighted return is calculated for each month then linked together.

training-reference/Terminology/Average_V.title: Average Value
training-reference/Terminology/Average_V.content:
Average Value

Average value of all portfolios at the end of the period.

training-reference/Terminology/Backing_i.title: Backing into a Beginning Value
training-reference/Terminology/Backing_i.content:
Backing into a Beginning Value

If a beginning value is not available, First Rate Performance uses the following calculation to derive one:

ABMV = (EMV + EA + I - ((1 - PF)P + (1 - NF)N))/UVR

Where:
• EMV is the ending value.
• EA is the ending accrual amount.
• I is the income amount (excluded when calculating total fund performance).
• PF is the positive factor.
• P is the positive flows.
• NF is the negative factor.
• N is the negative flows.
• UVR is a non-zero unit value return.

Because this calculation uses the UVR in the denominator, sectors with plugged returns will not foot with the records in the sector table (FRPSECTR).

training-reference/Terminology/Benchmark.title: Benchmark
training-reference/Terminology/Benchmark.content:
Benchmark

An independent hurdle rate that is used to judge the performance of a portfolio, composite or manager. The 'hurdle' may be a market index, a custom index, an absolute value or goal. The S&P 500, CPI, 90-Day Treasury, and Dow Jones, are examples of market indexes that are commonly used as benchmarks.

training-reference/Terminology/Beta.title: Beta
training-reference/Terminology/Beta.content:
Beta

The average performance volatility relative to a market representative benchmark. This statistic captures the sensitivity of a stock's return compared to that of the market. A beta greater than 1.00 means that the fund has greater systematic risk than the benchmark against which it is being compared. A beta less than 1.00 means that the fund has less systematic risk. Systematic risk refers to the risk inherent to the entire market or an entire market segment. Systematic risk, also known as "undiversifiable risk," "volatility" or "market risk," affects the overall market, not just a particular stock or industry.

training-reference/Terminology/Buy_Ins.title: Buy Ins
training-reference/Terminology/Buy_Ins.content:
Buy Ins

Buy ins are identified according to the following calculations:

PMKT ≤ (MKT - (MKT * PCT))

or

ABS(POS) < (MKT * PCT)

Where:
• PMKT is the previous market value.
• MKT is the ending market value.
• PCT is the Daily Sellout Buy In %.
• POS is the positive flow that is greater than zero.

For example, if an asset's previous value is $10 and this threshold is set to 90, any buy in that results in a value greater than or equal to $100 would be identified as a buy in (because $10 ≤ ($100 - ($100 * 90%))).

training-reference/Terminology/CUSIP.title: CUSIP
training-reference/Terminology/CUSIP.content:
CUSIP

Nine-digit ID number assigned to every asset in the United States by the Committee on Uniform Securities Identification Procedures.

training-reference/Terminology/Calendar_.title: Calendar Periods
training-reference/Terminology/Calendar_.content:
Calendar Periods

Calendar periods are based on the calendar month of the As of Date. For example, if the As of Date is 12/15/09, then the calendar period for a 1-month return is 12/01/09 through 12/15/09.

You can use the following periods with calendar option groups:
• Blank (null)
• Any number of months between 1 and 600
• ODR (One Day Return)
• MTD (Month-to-Date)
• QTD (Quarter-to-Date)
• FTD (Fiscal-Year-to-Date)
• YTD (Year-to-Date)
• ITD (Inception-to-Date)

training-reference/Terminology/Category.title: Category
training-reference/Terminology/Category.content:
Category

A group of sectors. A category is a four-letter code or a letter and number combination. When assets are broken down into Industry Groups, Benchmark Breakdowns, or based on Taxability, they are stored in detail sectors. To get a picture of a market sector like Total Equity or Total Fixed Income, a category is created like EQ or FX.

training-reference/Terminology/Closed_Ac.title: Closed Account
training-reference/Terminology/Closed_Ac.content:
Closed Account

A portfolio is considered closed or inactive when the value is zero for sector 01 for the current month. A portfolio is also considered closed when the maximum date in sector table (FRPSECTR) is less than the report as of date.

training-reference/Terminology/Composite.title: Composite
training-reference/Terminology/Composite.content:
Composite

Any grouping of portfolios for performance. Composites can represent a Master Trust, Style Composite, Client Relationship, and more. A single set of returns is created for a composite that represents the performance of the entire group of portfolios. Also known as an aggregate.

training-reference/Terminology/Composite.title: Composite Return Calculation
training-reference/Terminology/Composite.content:
Composite Return Calculation

Asset-weighted unit value returns (UVRs) are derived from the following calculation:

Asset-WeightedUVR = Σ(EMV + EA + I) - Σ([(1 - PF)P + (1 - NF)N])/ΣABMV

Where:
• EMV is the ending market value.
• EA is the ending accrual amount.
• I is the income amount (excluded when calculating Total Fund performance).
• PF is the positive factor.
• P is the positive flows.
• NF is the negative factor.
• N is the negative flows.
• ABMV is the adjusted beginning market value calculated as follows:

ABMV = BMV + BA + (PF)P + (NF)N

Where BMV is the prior market value (PMKT) for the current month, if available, or the market value (MKT) for the prior month, and BA is the prior accrual (PACC) for the current month, if available, or the accrual (ACC) for the prior month.

First Rate Professional computes an adjustment for daily UVRs when building composites only if the composite has neither (1) a previous market value (PMKT) on the daily performance table (FRPIPP), nor (2) a market value (MKT) for the previous month. Build performance continues to compute an adjustment for UVRs for monthly composites to account for plugged UVRs.

Equal-weighted UVRs are derived from the following calculation:

Equal-WeightedUVR = Σ(UVR)/n

Where:
• UVR is the unit value return for each portfolio at the TF level.
• n is the number of portfolios.

training-reference/Terminology/Date_Over.title: Date Overrides
training-reference/Terminology/Date_Over.content:
Date Overrides

Participation dates determine when a portfolio starts or ends in a composite. You can enter participation dates in First Rate Professional.

Date overrides control a portfolio's participation in a composite. Both the inception and ending date of a portfolio can be specified. Date overrides are needed when there is performance data outside the dates that are required for the composite.

training-reference/Terminology/Detail.title: Detail
training-reference/Terminology/Detail.content:
Detail

Data stored at the asset level. Detail information refers mainly to accounting information that can tie back to the investment accounting system like holdings, transactions, and asset data.

training-reference/Terminology/Dietz_Met.title: Dietz Method
training-reference/Terminology/Dietz_Met.content:
Dietz Method

See Money-Weighted Rate of Return.

training-reference/Terminology/Directed_.title: Directed Assets
training-reference/Terminology/Directed_.content:
Directed Assets

Assets mapped to a sector different than where the Industry mapping would place it. This may be due to the asset being unmanaged.

training-reference/Terminology/Diversifi.title: Diversification Allocation for Returns
training-reference/Terminology/Diversifi.content:
Diversification Allocation for Returns

This is a straight allocation of any remaining short-term monies and return. If only one of the two major categories exists, EQ - Equity or FX - Fixed, then the return is automatically equal to the Total Fund return. Otherwise the following occurs (note, example is for equity + cash):

1. Diversification of account using ABMV of EQ/FX.

Where:
• ABMVEQ is the adjusted beginning market value of the equity sector.
• ABMVFX is the adjusted beginning market value of the fixed sector.

2. Portion of short-term adjusted beginning value to add to the equity adjusted beginning value to create a new total equity ABMV.

Where:
• %EQ is the diversification of the portfolio, from step 1.
• ABMVST is the adjusted beginning market value of the short term sector.
• ABMVEQ is the adjusted beginning market value of the equity sector.

3. Portion of the equity return that contributes to equity + cash return.

Where:
• ABMVEQ is the adjusted beginning market value of the equity sector.
• NewABMVEC is the adjusted beginning market value of the equity and cash sectors.
• UVREQ is the unit value return of the equity sector.

4. Portion of the short-term return that contributes to the equity + cash return.

Where:
• NewABMVEC is the adjusted beginning market value of the equity and cash sectors.
• ABMVEQ is the adjusted beginning market value of the equity sector.
• UVRST is the unit value return of the short term sector.

5. Calculate equity + cash return.

training-reference/Terminology/Equal_Wei.title: Equal Weighted Composite Return
training-reference/Terminology/Equal_Wei.content:
Equal-Weighted Composite Return

This is an average of all the returns in a composite for a single sector, for a single month.

Where:
• UVR is the unit value return for the portfolio at the Total Fund level.
• n is the number of portfolios.

training-reference/Terminology/Excel_200.title: Excel 2000
training-reference/Terminology/Excel_200.content:
Excel 2000

You can view Excel 2000 files with Microsoft Excel 2000 or later — other spreadsheet applications may be able to import Excel files.

Excel 2000 format includes column headings; Excel spreadsheet format does not include column headings.

training-reference/Terminology/Excel_in_.title: Excel in a New Window
training-reference/Terminology/Excel_in_.content:
Excel in a New Window

When opening a spreadsheet generated by First Rate Performance, Internet Explorer can be configured to open the spreadsheet in the same browser window or in Microsoft Excel. If the report opens in the same browser window, the Microsoft Excel menu and toolbar are not available.

To configure Internet Explorer to open spreadsheets in Microsoft Excel:
1. In Windows Explorer (not Internet Explorer), choose Tools, Folder Options.
2. On the File Types tab, select XLS and click Advanced.
3. Under Actions, select Open, then clear the Browser in same window checkbox and click OK.

training-reference/Terminology/Extracts.title: Extracts
training-reference/Terminology/Extracts.content:
Extracts

Files sent by the accounting system. These files may contain a subset of the data on the system or they may be a copy of the system databases.

training-reference/Terminology/Factors.title: Factors
training-reference/Terminology/Factors.content:
Factors

Weighting of flows in a given period. The actual days in the performance period are used when calculating the number of days that a flow impacts performance.

The longer the flows affected performance, the closer the factor is to 1.000000. If the flows occur at the end of the performance period, then the factor will be closer to 0.000000. Both positive flows and negative flows are tracked and each is individually weighted with a factor.

When building daily performance, the factor can be set at the asset, sector, or global level by your First Rate Performance administrator.

Your administrator can direct whether the application uses the absolute value of flows when calculating the factor to use when building performance.

In this example, the Day Factor for all sectors is set to beginning of day (1.0):

Factor Calculation for 31-Day Month

Step One: Calculate Workflow
Day of Flow * Flow Amount

Day of Flow | Flow Amount | Workflow
3           | 500         | 1,500
4           | 100         | 400
31          | 900         | 27,900
            | 1500        | 29,800

Step Two: Calculate Average Day of Flow
(Total Workflow / Total Flow)
29,800 / 1500 = 19.86667

Step Three: Convert to Factor
(Days in Month - Average Day +1) / Days in Month
(31 - 19.86667 + 1 ) / 31 = 0.391398

Category Factor Calculation: Use the same process as above. However in step one, convert the factor for each category into a # Days Flow Affected Return by multiplying the factor by the number of days in the performance period.

training-reference/Terminology/Firm.title: Firm
training-reference/Terminology/Firm.content:
Firm

An installation of the First Rate Performance database. When using multi-currency performance, the firm is assigned a country; all prices loaded into the First Rate Performance database are loaded in the currency of the firm's country.

training-reference/Terminology/Flows.title: Flows
training-reference/Terminology/Flows.content:
Flows

The monies coming in and out of any performance sector, category or composite. Both positive and negative flows are tracked to provide a more accurate calculation.

training-reference/Terminology/Freeze_Da.title: Freeze Dates
training-reference/Terminology/Freeze_Da.content:
Freeze Dates

Your application administrator can restrict users from rebuilding historical performance data with global and portfolio-specific freeze dates. Administrators can also grant individual users the ability to override the global freeze date.

• With the global freeze date, your administrator enables the global freeze date option, and then records the date prior to which no one without the special override privilege can build performance.

Your administrator can also grant individual users the ability to override the global freeze date, meaning they can rebuild historical performance data.

• With portfolio-specific freeze dates, your administrator must first enable the option and specify a field on the portfolio table (FRPAIR) to contain the freeze date. Then First Rate Professional users can update that field in Process -> Edit Demographics.

When both freeze dates are in use, build performance uses whichever is most recent.

training-reference/Terminology/Gain_Loss.title: Gain Loss
training-reference/Terminology/Gain_Loss.content:
Gain/Loss

Total fund gain/loss is derived from the following calculation:

Sector gain/loss is derived from the following calculation:

Where:
• EMV is the ending market value.
• BMV is the beginning market value.
• F is the net flows.
• I is the income.

training-reference/Terminology/HTML.title: HTML
training-reference/Terminology/HTML.content:
HTML

Hypertext Markup Language. You can view HTML files with a Web browser, such as Internet Explorer or Netscape Navigator.

training-reference/Terminology/Holdings.title: Holdings
training-reference/Terminology/Holdings.content:
Holdings

Assets held by a portfolio at any point in time.

training-reference/Terminology/Inception.title: Inception Date
training-reference/Terminology/Inception.content:
Inception Date

The first date that financial data is used for portfolio and composite performance. In the First Rate application, inception date can set based on the first flow into the account or the month after the initial flow has occurred.

training-reference/Terminology/Income.title: Income
training-reference/Terminology/Income.content:
Income

The income earned and received for an asset.

training-reference/Terminology/Income_Re.title: Income Return
training-reference/Terminology/Income_Re.content:
Income Return

Represents the portion of the total return that is attributable to income. These rates of return are created in conjunction with principal returns.

The income rate of return is derived from the following calculation:

Where:
• RT is the total rate of return for the sector.
• RP is the principal rate of return for the sector. Principal return omits accrual and income terms from return calculation.

See also price return, principal return, and total return.

training-reference/Terminology/Interacti.title: Interaction Effect
training-reference/Terminology/Interacti.content:
Interaction Effect

Residual of allocation and selection effects. Shows impact of Weighting and Selectivity working together.

Where:
• W P is the weight of the portfolio.
• W M is the weight of the model portfolio.
• UVRP is the unit value return of the portfolio.
• UVRM is the unit value return of the model portfolio.

training-reference/Terminology/Internal_.title: Internal Rate of Return
training-reference/Terminology/Internal_.content:
Internal Rate of Return

The average change in value over the measurement period. More specifically, an IRR is an exact money weighted rate of return which provides the discount rate at which the initial investment equals the present value of the future capital flows.

training-reference/Terminology/Large_Cas.title: Large Cash Flow
training-reference/Terminology/Large_Cas.content:
Large Cash Flow

Occurs when a sector or category's positive or negative flow (net transaction total by portfolio/ processing month / sector or category / transaction date) equals or exceeds the sector or category's return calculation tolerance amount, which is derived by multiplying the sector or category's value (value + accrual value) for the prior performance period by the return calculation tolerance.

For example, suppose the value for a sector in the prior performance period is $100,000 and the return calculation tolerance is set to 10%, yielding a tolerance amount of $10,000. If a transaction date's positive flow is $7,000 and negative flow is $4,000, then neither flow is significant.

The net transaction totals include contributions, withdrawals, free receipts, free deliveries, sales, and purchases; it does not include income receipts or capital gain distributions. (See also Significant Cash Flow)

training-reference/Terminology/Maximum_R.title: Maximum Return
training-reference/Terminology/Maximum_R.content:
Maximum Return

Portfolio with the highest rate of return for the period.

training-reference/Terminology/Maximum_V.title: Maximum Value
training-reference/Terminology/Maximum_V.content:
Maximum Value

Value of largest portfolio at period end.

training-reference/Terminology/Median_Re.title: Median Return
training-reference/Terminology/Median_Re.content:
Median Return

Median return of the portfolio in the middle of the maximum and minimum values at end of period. For an even number of portfolios being evaluated, the average of the two median returns will be computed.

training-reference/Terminology/Median_Va.title: Median Value
training-reference/Terminology/Median_Va.content:
Median Value

Value of the portfolio in the middle of the maximum and minimum values at end of period. For an even number of portfolios being evaluated, the average of the two median values will be computed.

training-reference/Terminology/Minimum_R.title: Minimum Return
training-reference/Terminology/Minimum_R.content:
Minimum Return

Portfolio with the lowest rate of return for the period.

training-reference/Terminology/Minimum_V.title: Minimum Value
training-reference/Terminology/Minimum_V.content:
Minimum Value

Value of the smallest portfolio at end of period.

training-reference/Terminology/Modified_.title: Modified Dietz Calculation
training-reference/Terminology/Modified_.content:
Modified Dietz Calculation

The Modified Dietz is an approximation to the exact Money-Weighted Rate of Return.

training-reference/Terminology/Money_Wei.title: Money Weighted Rate of Return
training-reference/Terminology/Money_Wei.content:
Money Weighted Rate of Return

Measures the performance of the portfolio and considers the impact of external cash flows. A money-weighted rate of return best describes the rate of value growth or decline of a portfolio over time, as distinguished from a time-weighted rate of return, which is best to compare how well the manager performed versus benchmark.

The formula for an exact money weighted rate of return or Internal Rate of Return (IRR) provided below:

Where:
• BMV is the beginning market value.
• R is the rate of return.
• C is the cash flow at the start of the period.
• W is the weight.

CFA Institute Modified Dietz Method (Approximation Method)

Where:
• EMV is the ending market value.
• BMV is the beginning market value.
• C is the cash flow.
• W is the weighting factor of cash flows.

First Rate Professional's Modified Dietz Method

UVR = (EMV + EA + I - [(1 - PF)P + (1 - NF)N])/(BMV + BA + (PF)P + (NF)N)

Where:
• EMV is the ending market value.
• EA is the ending accrual amount.
• I is the income amount (included when calculating sector performance; excluded when calculating Total Fund performance).
• PF is the positive factor.
• P is the positive flows.
• NF is the negative factor.
• N is the negative flows.
• BMV is the beginning market value.
• BA is the beginning accrual amount.

training-reference/Terminology/Money_Wei.title: Money Weighted and Time Weighted Rates of Return
training-reference/Terminology/Money_Wei.content:
Money Weighted and Time-Weighted Rates of Return

A money-weighted rate of return best describes the rate of value growth or decline of a portfolio over time while a time-weighted rate of return best describes the performance of the manager.

For example, suppose you invest $100 in an asset that gains $10 its first month, but loses $10 its second month. Both the time-weighted rate of return and money-weighted rate of return are 0%. But suppose you invested another $100 at the beginning of the second month. The time-weighted return is still 0% because the performance of the underlying asset didn't change, but the money-weighted rate of return is now negative because there was more money invested during the period of lower performance.

When managers do not control the cash flowing in and out of their funds, the time-weighted rate of return minimizes the impact of cash flows and provides a return that more accurately measures their performance.

training-reference/Terminology/Net_of_Fe.title: Net of Fee Performance
training-reference/Terminology/Net_of_Fe.content:
Net-of-Fee Performance

Net-of-fee performance can be based on (1) a single total fund net of fee category, (2) mapping fee transactions to separate fee sectors rolled up into multiple net-of-fee categories, or (3) applying static basis point fees to specific portfolios / sectors.

• Fee amounts that are greater than zero are offset as a positive amount in the specified sector; fee amounts that are less than zero are offset as negative amounts.
• Daily fees will be calculated for daily portfolios.
• Fees will be written only to the roll-up country (00) for multi-currency portfolios.

GIPS standards recommend reporting gross-of-fees returns when presenting results to prospective clients but net of fee returns are appropriate when reporting clients' performance.

training-reference/Terminology/Open.title: Open
training-reference/Terminology/Open.content:
Open

A portfolio is considered active or open when the market value is non-zero for sector 01 for the current month. Also a portfolio is considered open when the maximum date in sector table (FRPSECTR) is equal to or greater than the report as of date or when the date override end date is equal to or greater than the report as of date.

training-reference/Terminology/Option_Re.title: Option Returns
training-reference/Terminology/Option_Re.content:
Option Returns

First, First Rate Professional's build performance batch in User Toolbox -> Lights Out uses the Modified Dietz method to calculate returns on option sectors:

Where:
• EMV is the ending market value.
• EA is the ending accrual amount.
• I is the income amount (included when calculating sector performance; excluded when calculating total fund performance).
• PF is the positive factor.
• P is the positive flows.
• NF is the negative factor.
• N is the negative flows.

When computing the Modified Dietz for an option sector, if the numerator is less than or equal to zero and the denominator is less than zero, First Rate Professional adjusts the UVR to provide an inverted rate of return.

The second way that build performance calculates option returns is the differential return calculation. This return is based on differential return sectors that you can set up in the Data Map -> Sector / Category -> Differential Return Sector screen.

First Rate Professional computes a return with and without option sectors as follows:
1. Compute a return for the category or sector that includes the option sector (With Category Sector).
2. Compute a return for the category or sector that excludes the option sector (Without Category Sector). Do this by subtracting all financial fields in the option sector from those in the With Category Sector and recalculate the factors.
3. Divide Return #1 by Return #2 to get the portion of total return attributable to options (Differential Return Sector).

For more information, see Building Differential Return Sectors.

training-reference/Terminology/PDF.title: PDF
training-reference/Terminology/PDF.content:
PDF

Portable Document Format. You can view PDF files with Adobe Acrobat Reader, available free from Adobe.

Earlier versions of Acrobat Reader display a maximum of 10 PDF files at one time; if you open subsequent PDF files, then Acrobat Reader starts closing files in the order in which they were opened.

training-reference/Terminology/Performan.title: Performance Triangle
training-reference/Terminology/Performan.content:
Performance Triangle

The Performance Triangle Report allows the user to see a periodic comparison of the components since inception. Since the periods increase from inceptions, a visual 'triangle' of information is produced.

Total Return — Return of the selected sector.
Benchmark — Return of the selected benchmark.
Difference — Total return minus benchmark.
Capital only — Total return calculated without income.
Income only — Total return minus capital return.

training-reference/Terminology/Plugged_R.title: Plugged Return
training-reference/Terminology/Plugged_R.content:
Plugged Return

A plugged return is a return that is manually entered because the underlying data cannot yield a return for a sector. For example, when returns come from an outside source or when history is being loaded, the underlying data may be unavailable or incomplete. If Build Performance were run for sectors with such data, the computed UVRs would be erroneous.

training-reference/Terminology/Policy.title: Policy
training-reference/Terminology/Policy.content:
Policy

The investment objective that dictates the asset allocation of a portfolio. The strategy might cause them to invest 80% of their money in equities and 20% in fixed income.

training-reference/Terminology/Portfolio.title: Portfolio
training-reference/Terminology/Portfolio.content:
Portfolio

Grouping of assets held by an investor. Sometimes the terms 'portfolio' and 'account' are used interchangeably but they can represent a distinction worth noting: a portfolio often refers to a grouping of assets held by an investor while an account may be one of many groupings in a portfolio.

training-reference/Terminology/Price_Ret.title: Price Return
training-reference/Terminology/Price_Ret.content:
Price Return

Price return is derived from the following calculation:

Where:
• ReturnP is the price return.
• EPR is the ending price.
• BPR is the beginning price.

See also income return, principal return, and total return.

training-reference/Terminology/Principal.title: Principal Return
training-reference/Terminology/Principal.content:
Principal Return

These returns are created when the holder or manager is interested in the portion of the return attributable to principal changes. This often occurs when the income on the portfolio belongs to one party and the principal belongs to another.

Principal return is derived from the following calculation:

Where:
• ReturnP is the principal return.
• EMV is the ending market value.
• BA is the beginning accrual.
• ADJ is the adjustment value calculation.
• BMV is the beginning market value.
• PF is the positive factor.
• P is the positive flows.
• NF is the negative factor.
• N is the negative flows.

See also income return, price return, and total return.

training-reference/Terminology/R_Squared.title: R Squared
training-reference/Terminology/R_Squared.content:
R-Squared

The portion of a fund's volatility that can be attributed to market volatility. For example, a portfolio or segment that has an R-squared of 1 behaves exactly like the market benchmark to which it is being compared. A portfolio or segment with an R-squared of 0.75 has three-fourths of its performance variation correlated with overall market movement and one-fourth of its variation unrelated to market movements.

training-reference/Terminology/Rate_of_R.title: Rate of Return
training-reference/Terminology/Rate_of_R.content:
Rate of Return

Rates of return are generated from the unit value return (UVR). Rates of return are unit values expressed as percentages, accomplished by taking the UVR and subtracting one from it and multiplying the result by one hundred.

Where:
• R is the rate of return.
• UVR is the unit value return.

training-reference/Terminology/Return_Ca.title: Return Calculation Frequency for Portfolios
training-reference/Terminology/Return_Ca.content:
Return Calculation Frequency for Portfolios

Indicates the frequency of return calculations. The return calculation frequency for portfolios is stored in the RCFREQ field of the FRPAIR table.

Portfolio-specific values for building daily performance:

Value | Meaning
------|--------
D     | Daily. Builds daily performance for the portfolio regardless of significant flows.
T     | Total fund. Builds daily performance for the portfolio only if the Total Fund sector (01) has a significant flow.
F     | Sector flow. Builds daily performance for the portfolio if any sector has a significant flow that is not flagged to skip the significant flow check.
M     | Monthly. Builds monthly performance for the portfolio.

training-reference/Terminology/Return_Ca.title: Return Calculation Frequency for Sectors
training-reference/Terminology/Return_Ca.content:
Return Calculation Frequency for Sectors

Indicates the frequency of return calculations. The return calculation frequency for sectors is stored in the SRCFREQ field of the FRPSECTR table.

Sector-specific values for building daily performance:

Value | Meaning
------|--------
A     | Adjustment value used.
D     | Daily performance.
F     | Significant flow.
M     | Monthly (default).
O     | After tax or net of fees (based on fee transactions) overlays used for daily performance return.
B     | Net of fees (based on basis points) used.
P     | Load Plugged Factors used.
T     | Total Fund.
U     | User modified.

Other values (R through Z) may appear if you have custom programs — for more information, contact your First Rate representative.

training-reference/Terminology/Return_Ca.title: Return Calculation Tolerance
training-reference/Terminology/Return_Ca.content:
Return Calculation Tolerance

Determines the significant flow tolerance for return calculations.

• The sector or category level return calculation tolerance is stored in the SRCTOL field in the FRPSECTR table and identifies how a specific sector's return was calculated.
• The portfolio level return calculation tolerance is stored in the RCTOL field in the FRPAIR table and identifies how future builds will calculate returns.

If you set a portfolio's return calculation tolerance between 1 and 99 percent, then the application calculates returns when the net transaction amount for the day exceeds the market value of the prior performance period by this percentage.

training-reference/Terminology/Rolling_P.title: Rolling Periods
training-reference/Terminology/Rolling_P.content:
Rolling Periods

Rolling periods are based on rolling back the exact number of days in the period from the As of Date. For example, if the As of Date is 12/15/09, then the rolling period for a 1-month return is 11/16/09 through 12/15/09.

You can use the following periods in rolling time periods:
• Blank (null)
• Any number of months between 1 and 600
• ODR (One Day Return)
• ITD (Inception-to-Date)

training-reference/Terminology/Secant_Me.title: Secant Method
training-reference/Terminology/Secant_Me.content:
Secant Method

The Secant method is an iterative process that produces the rate of return that will satisfy the equation involving starting and ending values plus cash flows. This process starts by using the linked time weighted return as its first guess for the money-weighted return, and adjusts the rate in a given direction depending on whether the calculated ending value is above or below the actual ending value. When the calculated value is equal to the actual ending value (or within an amount that the change would be less than one tenth of a basis point), the process stops.

When large flows (defined as a negative denominator in the Dietz calculation or first iteration of the Secant method) are encountered, the positive factor is plugged at .75 for and the negative factor at .25. Furthermore, if the money-weighted return calculation cannot get a residual amount close to 0 at the end of the 10th iteration, then the result of the first iteration of the Secant method is reported as the return.

If any iteration of the money-weighted return's Secant method results in a negative UVR, the UVR is reset to 100 to prevent an erroneous return.

training-reference/Terminology/Sector.title: Sector
training-reference/Terminology/Sector.content:
Sector

This is a grouping of assets; their summarized holdings, transactions, and returns.

training-reference/Terminology/Selectivi.title: Selectivity
training-reference/Terminology/Selectivi.content:
Selectivity

Selectivity is used in return attribution analysis. It values the manager's decision to invest in an asset. It is used in conjunction with weighting and is calculated as follows:

Where:
• UVRP is the unit value return of the portfolio.
• UVRB is the unit value return of the benchmark.
• W B is the weight of the benchmark

training-reference/Terminology/Sellouts.title: Sellouts
training-reference/Terminology/Sellouts.content:
Sellouts

Sellouts are identified according to the following calculations:

Where:
• MKT is the ending market value.
• PMKT is the previous market value.
• PCT is the Daily Sellout Buy In %.
• NEG is the negative flow that is less than zero.

For example, if an asset's previous value is $100 and the Daily Sellout Buy In % is set to 90%, any sale that results in a value less than or equal to $10 would be identified as a sellout (because $10 ≤ ($100 - ($100 * 90%))).

Buy ins are identified according to the following calculations:

or

Where:
• PMKT is the previous market value.
• MKT is the ending market value.
• PCT is the Daily Sellout Buy In %.
• POS is the positive flow that is greater than zero.

For example, if an asset's previous value is $10 and this threshold is set to 90, any buy in that results in a value greater than or equal to $100 would be identified as a buy in (because $10 ≤ ($100 - ($100 * 90%))).

training-reference/Terminology/Significa.title: Significant Cash Flow
training-reference/Terminology/Significa.content:
Significant Cash Flow

Although sometimes used to mean large cash flow, significant cash flow is defined by the GIPS Standards as the "level at which the firm determines that a client directed external cash flow may temporarily prevent the firm from implementing the composite strategy, thereby causing the portfolio to no longer be representative of the composite strategy." (See also Large Cash Flow)

training-reference/Terminology/Standard_.title: Standard Deviation Return
training-reference/Terminology/Standard_.content:
Standard Deviation Return

Distribution of returns around average rates of return equal-weighted average at end of period.

training-reference/Terminology/Summary.title: Summary
training-reference/Terminology/Summary.content:
Summary

Everything represented at the sector level and above. At the sector level, individual detail holdings and transactions are not visible.

training-reference/Terminology/Time_Weig.title: Time Weighted Rate of Return
training-reference/Terminology/Time_Weig.content:
Time-Weighted Rate of Return

Measures manager performance by minimizing the impact of cash flows beyond the manager's control. A time-weighted rate of return is best to compare how well the manager performed versus a benchmark, as distinguished from a money-weighted rate of return, which best describes the rate of value growth or decline of a portfolio over time.

A time-weighted rate of return is generated by linking multiple, continuous money-weighted rates of return, as shown in the following calculation:

T = UVR1 * UVR2 * UVR3...UVRn

Where:
• T is the time-weighted rate of return.
• UVR1 * UVR2 * UVR3...UVRn are the money-weighted returns for several contiguous periods.

Because the money-weighted returns are calculated separately and then linked together, each money-weighted return has an equal impact on the final time-weighted rate of return regardless of differences in the monetary values of assets managed during each period.

training-reference/Terminology/Tolerance.title: Tolerance
training-reference/Terminology/Tolerance.content:
Tolerance

A tolerance is a range of values relative to the benchmark that you select for sectors and categories in the Table Values Editor in First Rate Professional. For example, you can set a tolerance so that if a category or sector's return is 5% higher or lower than a specific benchmark, it is flagged on the report.

training-reference/Terminology/Total_Fun.title: Total Fund Return
training-reference/Terminology/Total_Fun.content:
Total Fund Return

The return for Total Fund usually falls between the Equity and Fixed returns. Over multiple periods, however, the cumulative return for Total Fund may fall outside the cumulative returns for Equity and Fixed. This is true because the weighted average of the products is not equal to the product of the weighted averages, especially if the weights change.

For example, suppose a fund starts with $100 in Equity and $100 in Fixed and has the following returns:

Period 1 | Period 2 | Return | Cumulative

Equity:
Beg Mkt Val: $100 | End Mkt Val: $105 | 5% | 
Beg Mkt Val: $105 | End Mkt Val: $84 | -20.0% | -16%

Fixed:
Beg Mkt Val: $100 | End Mkt Val: $101 | 1% | 
Beg Mkt Val: $101 | End Mkt Val: $104 | 3.0% | 4%

Total Fund:
Beg Mkt Val: $200 | End Mkt Val: $206 | 3% | 
Beg Mkt Val: $206 | End Mkt Val: $188 | -8.7% | -6%

In this example, the Total Fund return falls between the Equity and Fixed returns for each month and the cumulative period.

But if $100 is moved from Equity to Fixed in the middle of period 2, the following returns occur:

Period 1 | Period 2 | Cumulative

Equity:
Beg Mkt Val: $100 | End Mkt Val: $105 | Return: 5% | 
Beg Mkt Val: $105 | End Mkt Val: $4 | Flow: -$100 | Flow Factor: 0.50 | Return: -1.82% | 2.9%

Fixed:
Beg Mkt Val: $100 | End Mkt Val: $101 | Return: 1% | 
Beg Mkt Val: $101 | End Mkt Val: $207 | Flow: $100 | Flow Factor: 0.50 | Return: 3.97% | 5.0%

Total Fund:
Beg Mkt Val: $200 | End Mkt Val: $206 | Return: 3% | 
Beg Mkt Val: $206 | End Mkt Val: $211 | Return: 2.43% | 5.5%

In this example, even though the return for Total Fund at the end of each period falls between the Equity and Fixed returns, the return for Total Fund for the cumulative period falls outside the Equity and Fixed returns.

training-reference/Terminology/Total_Man.title: Total Managed v Total Fund
training-reference/Terminology/Total_Man.content:
Total Managed v. Total Fund

Total Managed is a category or combination of all sectors managed by the portfolio investment officer. The return for Total Managed will almost always differ from the return for Total Fund, even if the portfolio includes only managed sectors.

The flows that impact the Total Fund return include contributions and distributions from the portfolio. However, Total Managed flows are the sum total of all managed sector's flows — all purchase, sale, receipt, delivery, contribution and distribution activities and their timings impact the Total Managed returns. In an actively managed portfolio, this may result in flows that are greater than 10% of the Total Managed category's value.

training-reference/Terminology/Total_Ret.title: Total Return
training-reference/Terminology/Total_Ret.content:
Total Return

The total return is determined by the Modified Dietz:

Derived from the Modified Dietz method:

Where:
• EMV is the ending market value.
• EA is the ending accrual amount.
• I is the income amount.
• PF is the positive factor.
• P is the positive flows.
• BMV is the beginning market value.
• BA is the beginning accrual amount.
• NF is the negative factor.
• N is the negative flows.

When computing the Modified Dietz for a sector, if the numerator is less than or equal to zero and the denominator is less than zero, defined as a short sell, First Rate Performance adjusts the UVR to provide an inverted rate of return.

See also income return, price return, and principal return.

training-reference/Terminology/Transacti.title: Transaction Identifier
training-reference/Terminology/Transacti.content:
Transaction Identifier

The T_IDENT field on the Transaction Code file. The transaction codes are stored in the FRPTCD table.

training-reference/Terminology/Transacti.title: Transactions
training-reference/Terminology/Transacti.content:
Transactions

The buys, sells, contributions, withdrawals, asset receipts, asset deliveries, and income activities used in portfolio accounting.

training-reference/Terminology/Uninveste.title: Uninvested Cash
training-reference/Terminology/Uninveste.content:
Uninvested Cash

The residual cash in a portfolio at the end of the month that is not invested in an investment vehicle.

training-reference/Terminology/Unit_Valu.title: Unit Value Return UVR
training-reference/Terminology/Unit_Valu.content:
Unit Value Return (UVR)

The unit value return (UVR) is the result of the application's money-weighted return calculation as well as the time-weighted return calculation before it is converted to a percentage. A unit value return is a relative measure showing the change that occurs to 1.00 monetary units invested at the beginning of the time period. If the unit value return is greater than 1.00 the value of the monetary unit increased. If it is less than 1.00 the value has decreased. This term is specific to First Rate applications but is synonymous with a Wealth Relative Return or Wealth Ratio.

training-reference/Terminology/Weighting.title: Weighting
training-reference/Terminology/Weighting.content:
Weighting

Weighting is used in Return Attribution Analysis. It values the manager's decision of how much to weight the portfolio in a particular asset. It is calculated as follows:

W = (Wp - WB) * (UVRP - UVRBC)

Where:
• W is the weight.
• W P is the weight of the portfolio.
• W B is the weight of the benchmark.
• UVRP is the unit value return of the portfolio.
• UVRBC is the unit value return of the benchmark's category.

training-reference/Terminology/Workstati.title: Workstation Directory
training-reference/Terminology/Workstati.content:
Workstation Directory

The location where temporary files and reports are created and saved.
